text:
I've made this for years, and it's always excellent. I do now make some modifications to make it more healthy. First, I sautee about 1/2 c. onion with a couple of garlic cloves in a bit of olive oil, and add a 1/2 c. each carrot and celery and sautee it for a couple of minutes until softened before adding the broth, water and chicken. I also use 2 c. skim milk, and cut the butter to 6 tablespoons, and the flour to 1/2 c. It's still thick, creamy and delicious but cuts out a considerable amount of fat and calories, and adding vegetables gives it extra flavor and body. Perfect.

text:
To be honest, I did a number of things differently with this, so I guess this is a review of a VARIATION of this recipe. After reading through it I knew  I wanted a heartier soup with more depth of flavor. I sauteed a few strips of bacon, then added chopped celery, onion, mushrooms and a big clove of garlic. Since I used a larger package of rice I decreased the amount of flour to 1/3 c. to allow for the added thickness the extra rice would provide, and I used 1 c. cream and 1 c. milk.  I also added an extra chicken breast and, during the final simmering, a healthy splash of white wine, probably a good 1/2 cup. The result was positively outstanding!

text:
This is an oustanding, restaurant quality soup with great flavor. You do not need to use heavy cream. I have made this with 1% milk several times with fantastic results and it is still plenty rich and thick. Make sure to add some carrots and celery, as the soup all by itself seems like its missing something.

text:
I’d describe this soup as “comforting”.  The flavors and thickness turn a gray day into a great day.  I read others’ advice and recommend these changes: start by sautéing ½ cup each of diced onion, celery, and carrots plus 1-2 minced garlic cloves using 1 tablespoon of the ½ cup of butter.  Then add the broth (5 cups), water (3 cups), and chicken.  For the roux, cut the flour to ½ cup and use 1½ cup milk instead of heavy cream. Once it’s smooth (not thick), add it to the broth/chicken/rice and add ¼ cup white wine if desired.  A friend of mine, who is a restaurant connoisseur, declared the soup to be restaurant quality!  What a compliment!

text:
Spectacular!  Will be making this often during the winter.  I hunted high and low for a 4.5 oz package of the quick cooking rice with seasoning.  Couldn't find it - had to use a 6.5 oz box with seasoning packet.  I cooked the rice separately (didn't add seasoning packet) - it cooked for 25 min.  While the rice was cooking I poached the chicken - both took 25 min. so they were finished together. Then I proceeded with the recipe but I left out the 2 cups of water since I was adding cooked rice.  (the uncooked rice would have absorbed the 2 cups of water if I had used it).  I used the seasoning packet as directed.  I did find that 3/4 cup of flour was too much - I was slowly adding it so I was able to stop before it was too late - I used probably about 1/2 cup.  Anyway - this was the creamiest, thickest soup I have ever tasted and the flavor was great - oh, I followed the suggestions of other reviewers and sauted some onion, carrots and celery and I am glad I did.  It was much thicker the next day so I just thinned it a little with chicken broth - milk would have done the trick too.  Thank you so much submitter.

text:
Great recipe! My whole family could not get enough. 

I did have a few minor changes. I added 1/2 cup carrots, 1/2 cup celery and 1/2 onion. I sauteed the vegetables in a little bit of olive oil and garlic. Like other reviewers, I also cut the cream in half and used milk as a replacement(I would recommend 1 or 2% and not skim). I would also recommend Uncle Bens wild rice. Great flavor!

Will make again!

Very good soup.  I just had wild rice I purchased from the health-food store, so I didn't have a seasoning packet.  I used the following to season the rice: 2 Tbsp finely chopped onion, ½ tsp dry parsley flakes, ¼ tsp garlic powder, ¼ tsp onion powder, 1 tsp ground turmeric, ½ tsp ground cumin, ¼ tsp ground ginger.  Will definitely make again!

text:
WOW!!!!  This is my new favorite allrecipes recipe and my new favorite soup.  I ate the entire pot (save the one bowl my bf got) over the weekend.  So, I made another pot today.  I think it would've been fabulous with no changes made but naturally I couldn't help myself.  Changes I made...used 3 cups homemade stock and 3 cups water/ chicken base (Minor's brand).  Because I used chicken base I omitted the salt.  I chopped a small onion and clove of garlic and cooked for a minute in butter/seasoning mixture before adding flour.  I reduced flour to 1/2 cup.  Used half and half instead of cream.  For the chicken I used 1 giant chicken breast that I grilled on my foreman and used the allrecipes Cajun Chicken marinade.  So the chicken was pretty heavily seasoned.  The folks who said this is restaurant quality are totally spot on.   Tonight I'm making bread bowls and serving it in that.

I use Uncle Ben's quick cooking Long Grain and Wild rice, how easy can it get? I use a 16 oz. carton of half and half instead of heavy cream. I add chopped celery and carrots and cook them with the chicken. This is so thick and rich, absolutely delicious.

text:
Pretty good, and really easy to make! For the chicken, I bought a warm, already-roasted chicken from the deli section of the grocery store -- delicious. I substituted the heavy cream for skim evaporated, and I used Rice-a-Roni brand instant rice. My only criticism is that it tasted like a slightly better-quality canned soup: the chicken was better than you'd ever find in a can, but the flavor, though tasty, wasn't terribly unique.

I made this soup per the recipe, using fresh baked chicken breast that was lightly seasoned with salt and pepper and cubed instead of shredding. text:
I've made this as is and it's very good.  I've just made it with the following changes that other reviewers have used and it came out AMAZING!! BF couldn't get enough!  I sauteed onion, garlic, and bacon in olive oil.  I then added some chopped celery and carrots and cooked until softened.  I added that mixture to the broth, water, chicken mixture and cooked according to the recipe. (Note - I used Uncle Ben's Wild Rice Mix.  Very good and healthier than the other brands at the grocery store)
For the cream mixture, I decreased to 6 tbsp of butter and 1/2 cup flour.  I also used 1 cup skim and 1 cup whole milk rather than 2 cups heavy cream and it was still rich, yet healthier.  I also added about 1/2 cup white wine to the soup during the last 15 minutes of cooking.
Next time I'll use shallots rather than onion to give it more oomph but it really is delicious either as is or modified to your liking.  Hope you give it a try!!

text:
This is truely restaraunt quality soup with a few additions. So easy too! I used a rotissire chicken.  I do think the addition of veggies gives it more depth. I added a bag of frozen celery, carrots and onions that I got at kroger. It's called "mirepoix style blend" Worked perfectly. No chopping needed :) I used half and half and only half of the flour called for & it was still plenty thick & creamy. Also added a bay leaf, a tsp of sage and garlic powder while it was cooking through.. I think it really helped with the flavors! Next time, might add a little tyme.  Served with Hawaiian Sweet Rolls.  Yum!

This recipe is the best!  You must try this recipe.  I used all chicken broth for the water for more flavor.  For a short cut I used Perdue Honey roasted chicken in the blue box all ready cooked and just chopped into smaller pieces.  The 4.5 oz pkg of rice is the Mahatma brand with the brown label.  First time I made it I used regular heavy cream.  Second time I used half and half.  Both were great but the heavy cream is just that, too heavy.  Use half and half.  I double the recipe the 2nd time I made it.  This will be a regular recipe in our house.

text:
Very good recipe that works well in a crockpot! Add the 2 frozen chicken breasts, a box of Rice-a-Roni Long Gain and Wild Rice with seasoning packet, 4 cups chicken broth (or 3 cans), 2 cups water. 1 cup chopped celery, and 1 cup chopped carrots in a large crockpot. Cook on high for 4 hours or 6 hours on low. Make rue like original recipe suggests (except I used 2 cups whole milk) and add to crockpot. Cook 15 min. more on low.

text:
Tasty recipe! Like many others, I too started with browning onion, celery, carrots and garlic. Rather than make my roux later and blend, I chose to start my veggies in 6 tablespoons of butter, and after 5 minutes, added my 1/2 cup off flour before adding my 1 1/2 cup of plain wild rice and 4 cups of Better Than Boullion Chicken broth (I am not a fan of packaged seasoned rice), brought it to a boil, than simmer for ~50 minutes. At the end I added 1 cup of half-n-half and 1 cup of skim milk. Seasoned with coasher salt and pepper. It turned out creamy and delicious. Next time I might experiment with herbs like Thyme or Rosemary.

text:
Wow YUM!! I did add onion and carrots. I cooked them slow in a skillet with raw chicken breast. When the chicken was browned and veggies softened I added a splash of sherry then continued as written. The sherry added a nutty flavor without being over powering. EXCELLENT.~*~UPDATE: when using cooked chicken in this recipe, just throw it in at the very end. The soup will warm the chicken without making it chewy. ***UPDATE AGAIN**** I added extra wild rice that I had soaked over night. Also, a little bit of swiss cheese in the cream base works good with cooking sherry. I keep re-inventing this recipe and it gets better and better!

text:
I gave this recipe 4/5 because you must have veggies for it to be good. I recommend browning some mushrooms and then satueeing celery/ onion/ carrots and then garlic. I used 2% milk, though skim would have been fine. Cream is not needed. i cut down on butter to 6 TBS and used light. I used shredded rotisserie chicken but would also in the future use whatever was on hand. Great start to a recipe but veggies is a must! Also I added more stock at the end to make it more soup like and less stew like.

text:
Delicious!  And a hit with the kids too. Because I had just plain non-instant wild rice, I had to make some alterations, but stuck to the recipe except having to account for cooking longer with more liquid and making my own seasoning mix.  I used the same amount of rice, but doubled the water - brought to a boil, added rice, and then covered tightly and simmered for 40 minutes - then added some sliced and diced veggies (carrots, celery, sweet red pepper, onion), brought back to a boil and simmered low for another 20 minutes before adding the roux. For the seasoning mix I used a teaspoon of ground sage, 1/2 teaspoon of savory, and heaping teaspoon of dry tarragon.  Oh, and I also only had about a cup of heavy cream on hand, so I supplemented with whole milk and it was perfect - so you could probably get away with "half and half" in this recipe.

text:
I have a gluten intolerant person in the house, so I modified it a tiny bit. Basically, I eliminated the roux. I started with the 4 cups of broth, and 1 cup of water. I had raw tenderloins, so cut those up and boiled them in the broth, along with celery, carrot and onion. I then added the rice mix (gf kind) and cooked that. While that was cooking to get the rice and veggies tender, I added a can of evaporated milk and about 1 1/2 Tablespoons of cornstarch, blended together as the thickener. I also threw in a couple handfuls of frozen corn. It turned out great. I know this is not the exact recipe as written, but it's nice to know that it can be made gf and still be acceptable to a family having dinner together.

text:
I've made this soup a few times now and it's one of our favorites.  I never use all of the flour called for (makes it too goopy and thickens fine without all of it) I also just took some of the other suggestions and sauteed a little onion and garlic before adding in the broth, water and chicken to the pot.  The first couple of times I made the soup I used the cream, but tried it tonight with 2% milk and it was just as good (it lost a little "richness" due to the swap out) never the less it was still incredibly thick and creamy. It was great, we had the pleasure without the guilt. I always shred a good cup of carrot to throw in when I add the rice and I like to chop celery for some great flavor and texture too.  My 5 year old (who's quite choosy) LOVES it and calls dibs on the leftovers every time I make it. Incredible recipe - thank you so much for sharing it! ***Update - used Specialty "Chicken Broth with White Wine and Herbs" in place of regular and it blew our minds!

Excellent! I doubled the recipe since I had about 8 c. of homemade chicken stock on hand. Using suggestions from other reviewers I sauteed 4 cloves garlic, minced along w/ 1 c. each of onion, celery and sliced carrots and added this to the simmering stock. I used 4 c. of 2% reduced fat milk instead of the cream, but didn't have to double the butter or flour for thickening. The soup thickened up great with just the single recipe amount. I served this with a warm loaf of ciabatta bread... the whole family really enjoyed it! Thanks so much Stephanie!

Lovestohost, you were SO right about this soup. I had part of a huge package of baby bellas that I had to use up so I cut them up and threw them in with the onion and garlic that I sauteed in the butter. I used all homemade chicken broth instead of part water, and I used a box of Uncle Ben's mushroom wild rice. Very, VERY good. Quite comforting. And this really only took about a half hour, as I started two pots at once. The pot with the rice and the soup pot with the vegetables. This one's a keeper. This really made a bad day good. Thanks to the submitter and suggester. EDIT: I find this works much better with cornstarch than flour.

text:
I'm going to only give this a 4 star but it is by far a 5 star recipe and here's why.   There is no reason to use 2 different pots to put this soup together.  That's my reason for 4 stars. This is what I did.  I added carrots, celery and onion  per other reviewers suggestions in a dutch oven.  I cooked my veges in 6 Tbsp of butter til all of it was soft, about 10 minutes, maybe a bit less .  I then added the cooked, shredded chicken and rice to 48 ozs.  of chicken broth in this pot .  I used a 6.5 box of Uncle Ben's quick wild rice recipe.  There is no such thing as a 4.5 size box  of it.  This is probably a mistake to whomever looks over this recipe before it's allowed to be submitted.  They do change things.  I know from personal experience.  I then mixed together 1/2 cup of half/ half, 1 1/2 c. of 1 % milk,  flour and  wild rice seasoning. I whisked together in a bowl til there were on more lumps.  I then added it to the chicken, broth, veges  and rice and let it cook for the allotted amount of time.  No lumps and it saved a step and an extra dish to clean.   The extra veges were a bonus but I'm sure this soup would have been just a yummy without it.  I just like extra flavor.

LOVE THIS! The only thing I did differently: I took the advice of others, and sautéed onion, garlic carrots and celery in olive oil, then added it into the soup. I'm going to preface this by saying I made quite a few tweaks, but I never would have anywhere to begin w/out this recipe, so I'm rating it anyway, because it's a great soup! I sauteed onions & garlic in a little EVOO and added them to the water/broth mixture.  I halved the butter (and then adjusted the flour and milk accordingly) to lighten it up a bit.  I also subbed skim milk for heavy cream to again lighten it up some.  When I added the *cream* mixture to the broth, I added a bag of frozen peas and a can of canned corn (I do NOT rec canned corn, as it did give it a little of that *canned corn* taste, but it was l had.  I will def use frozen shoepeg corn next time!) to up the nutrient level.  At first bite, I wasn't sold.  Then, I kept eating.  This is very good and very simple!  I'd cooked my chicken breast in the crock pot a couple of days before, so the soup took less than 1/2 hour to make.  At service, I added a dash of nothing special canned parm cheese to the top and I loved it!  It really added a little something.  THANKS for a great base recipe!

text:
I could not find anywhere in the supermarkets over here, easy cook rice that came with a sachet of seasoning powder. What we do have are a few rice packets that come with rice already flavoured. So I decided to use easy cook long grain and wild rice that came plain and add my own seasoning. Not knowing what flavour seasoning comes with your rice over there I used black pepper, sage, celery salt and lemon peel. I also sauteed onions and mushrooms before adding all the other ingredients. Yummy, but I think I will have to tinker with the seasoning I used to get it spot on. Shame I couldn't make it as you guys do though!

If you can't find the QUICK cook rice either, use the regular Long Grain and Wild rice, but  cook the rice in the broth with step 1 according to the package instructions.)Wow, great soup! city:

country:
None
text:
Thick and creamy! I easily "healthified" this recipe and it couldn't taste better! This is a list of the specific products and amounts I used: low-sodium chicken broth, around 16-20 ounces of diced chicken breasts, Uncle Ben's Quick Cooking Long Grain & Wild Rice, 1/2 cup of flour, 1/2 cup Blue Bonnet margarine, 2 cups 1% milk, 3/4 cup of each carrots and celery, a small diced onion, and around 1/2 tsp minced garlic. I followed the advice of other reviewers and sauteed the vegetables and garlic with a smidgen of olive oil before adding the broth, water & chicken. Only 280 calories per serving (serves 8) using my modifications. P.S. It tastes just as good heated up later. My family loves this soup!!!

Always the hit of the party. I too add the fresh sauteed veggies: onions, carrots, celery, mushrooms and use regular Uncle Ben's Wild Rice. I cook all on stove and then put in crock pot to keep warm and allow rice to continue cooking. I always make double batches (one at a time and then combine) and NEVER have any left overs. Adding a little touch of sherry and/or white wine adds to the flavor and when using cream, helps to reduce thickness if desired. This is a top recipe

text:
This is a really delicious soup.  I'm trying to stay a little on the health conscience side so I changed a few things.  I added an onion finely chopped, two carrots diced, and some poultry seasoning.  I also didn't have any chicken broth so I used chicken boullion with water.  I also used two cups of whole milk with a little cornstarch in place of the cream, 3 tablespoons of butter instead of a whole stick and just added enough flour to make the roux.  I didnt have the rice with the flavor packet so I used an Uncle Ben's wild and brown 90 second packet instead.  This soup is great for a cold night and is definitely a keeper.

text:
This is funny.  Everyone loves the recipe but no one follows it.  LOL.  Okay, I replaced heavy cream with %1 milk, added carrots, celery, onion, and 1/2 cup of white wine.  I ditched wild rice/packet for plain jasmine rice and it was still very tasty.

Funny thing is that the rice absorbed the soup within an hour.  So I had these odd 'clumps' of soup as leftovers.  Soup Softballs, if you will.  When reheating, add at least a cup of water and it's good.

Display Name:
Julie62

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/154.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
"Yummy soup," said my son. Sums up a thumbs up. UPDATE: This has become one of our favorite soups. I add diced carrot, onion and celery and saute in olive oil.  While the veggies are softening, I heat 2 cups of water in the microwave and added 2 Knorr's chicken bouillion cubes, stirring to dissolve. Then I pour the  in the Long Grain & Wild Rice (Rice A Roni 4.3 oz.) into the broth to soak while I wait on the veggies. When the veggies are soft, I add the butter (1 stick) to them and stir all together (no sense in dirtying another pan.) Then I whisk in the seasoning packet, 1/2 c. flour (3/4 c. made it too thick for me), then the cream to the veggie mix. When the roux is done, I gradually add the broth and water, stirring to combine. Then let simmer for 25 minutes or until rice has softened. UPDATE #2: I made this full-fat for company. While it was divine right then, after storing it, I saw all the butter that separated on top. Next time I'll be using a light version for sure!

Absolutely delicious!  I made this for my family, and a husband who hates soup.  He really liked it and said he wanted it again.  My MIL and SIL thought it was awesome also.  As a sidenote, I did follow the direction of some other reviews.  I added 1/2 cup each of carrots, onions, and celery (sauteed in 1 Tbsp. butter).  I subbed milk for the cream and did 5 cups of broth/3 cups water.  I used Rice-a-Roni 'Long Grain & Wild Rice'.  It comes in a 4.3 oz box.  It was perfect.  I also used leftover Rotisserie Chicken.  My search is over for a good chicken-wild rice soup.  This is the best!

userID:

Display Name:
Michelle Roth-Kiva

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not bad. If for nothing else, I appreciate the fact that this is made with natural, wholesome (albeit FATTENING!) ingredients. Having said this, I think I would have liked this MUCH less had I not made several MUCH needed changes. To start, I added 1/2 c. each of chopped onion, celery and carrot. I also added a couple cloves of minced garlic. I sauteed my garlic / onion in ~ 2 T vegetable oil and then added the rest of my veggies and sauteed until tender and *almost* cooked cooked thru. My only other changes were to add 1/2 c. of white wine (chardonnay) to my roux mixture (it seemed a tad thick otherwise) and season with a GENEROUS dose of s&p prior to serving. Even still, my hubs and I felt this could use a bit more tweaking. We both felt this was skimpy on two key ingredients - chicken and rice. NOTE: Don't sweat it if you are unable to locate the 4.3 oz. box of rice called for. The larger, standard size (6.4 oz.) one worked just fine (and we still thought we could have used more). DO be sure that you are using INSTANT rice tho! Sourdough bread bowls were a perfect way to serve our soup. A sprinkling of sharp cheddar really hit the spot. I'm glad to have given your recipe a try, but it needs a lot more tweaking to suit us. Thanks Stephanie! :-)

text:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE this recipe!  I found it after moving to a town with no Panera Bread, which is the only place I've found that serves my favorite soup.  This replicates it well and might be even better! 

The only modifications I make are substituting 1 cup half and half and 1 cup skim milk for the heavy cream.  I think it turns out very creamy and healthier.  I also add carrots.  

It's also very easy to make if you cook your chicken in the slow cooker the day before (in 2 cups water, for 4 hours on high)... it makes shredding a breeze, and cuts down on time in the kitchen when making the soup. :-)

text:
This was a very simple and easy recipe to make. I made this exactly as the recipe stated so that I could critique the soup in its original recipe form. First, some have had trouble finding 4.5ounce packages. I'll tell you that I think only Rice-o-Roni has them in packages that small for MOST stores like Publix. Next, the prep and cooking time are all wrong. A roux takes at least five minutes and thats not including if you have to cook the chicken rather than buying precooked boneless chicken. Anyway, once you get rolling with that and are able to serve up a hot bowl of this stuff it is absolutely splendid. As others have said, it's great for a cold day, heck make two pots of it for two cold days! You won't find a better recipe of this type of soup on this site.

text:
I made this soup over the weekend. I used left over turkey meat, as that what was in my frig. I never would have thought of using boxed wild rice, but the seasoning pack is key to the flavor in this soup. I also added in veggies (onions, celery, spinach, and carrots) since I have to hide veggies into meals so that my family will eat them. I only used 1/4 cup butter and 1/4 C fat free 1/2 & 1/2 to get the creamy texture without all the fat.

text:
As written, 4 stars.  With adjustments, 5.  I sauteed 1/2-3/4 cup each diced onion (1 small), celery (1 stalk) & carrot (2 small) and 2 cloves minced garlic in the butter (used 6 tbsp) then added the flour (1/2 cup) and 2% milk (not cream) as directed.  Also, can't find "quick cooking" wild rice mix here so used regular - just cooked it in the full broth / water mixture called for in this recipe (omitted the margarine required on the box) until the rice was tender, then added in the chicken (about 1 lb) to heat through when it was cooked.  Combined the milk/broth mixtures and finished as directed.  Absolutely delicious.

Display Name:
JARRIE

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/926498.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely 5 stars. I cooked my frozen chicken breasts in the broth/water mixture, because I wanted the chicken water for my soup (husband is sick, wanted whatever magic that cooked chicken has to be in my soup, not poured down the drain). Shredded them in the broth. It takes about an hour using 2 completely frozen breast halves. If it doesn't shred nicely, it isn't done yet, keep boiling. You lose some fluid this way, so you'll need to adjust at the end by adding more broth, water, or milk, whatever suits you. Taste it first to see which of the three you want. I tend to like my soups a wee bit thin, so for the roux I only used 4 TB butter and 4 TB flour. I did wind up thinning mine with skim milk (overall around 2 cups, but I changed the method some, so that affected the liquid ratio). This was just overall far more wonderful than I really expected & I could not be more pleased. I wish my husband's taste buds were working properly so he could've fully appreciated it! Thanks for the recipe, I will make it again :) (BTW, if you do decide to boil your chicken in the broth, whether frozen or raw, in either case, stuff will float up to the top. Skim it off and trash it, you don't want to eat that part. It won't hurt you though if you forget. It's just jibbles of fat.)

userID:
1447121
Display Name:
cynjne
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/60013.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one of those sleeper type recipes. You know,very popular seasonally, usually autumn and winter. It then slips away while we enjoy the lighter fare of spring and summer returning again as the temperature drops. With few ingredients this is a soup that is definitely not stingy on flavour. I added about 1/4 C. small diced carrot, only to enhance the colour. Not having heavy cream, I opted for a mixture of 1/2 and 1/2 and milk. The finished soup has a perfect consistency while still warm. It will later require thinning. I suppose I am at a point in my own cooking where roux is no longer a four letter word. Which, by the way, was a long time coming and made for some mighty horrid outcomes. Everything was working as it should roux-wise here, but I became worried at the thickness while the cream was being incorporated. Thick enough to get tangled up and stuck inside the whisk even! Experience told me to keep adding the liquid as directed even though the potted floury blob didn't look promising. Keep whisking, and babysit, as this easily becomes overdone, quickly browning or even burning the pot bottom. More so, if using a thin (cheap :-})pot like me. Don't give up. It will work! Overall I think this is a deliciously fine soup. Thanks for the recipe.

A few changes that I made were: 1) I first sauteed 1/2 cup each of celery, onion carrots and 1-2 garlic cloves. 2) I increased the broth to 5 cups and increased the water to 3 cups. 3)Instead of 2 cups heavy cream I used to cups 2% milk. 4)Reduced the flour to 1/2 cup. text:
AMMMAAAZZZIIINNGGG!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  But instead I didn't use the wild rice seasoning packet/quick cook rice so (this was for 12 servings btw):  1 small leek sliced 1 onion chopped 2-3 stalks of celery chopped *Saute in butter  Then add 1 1/2 chicken breast (shredded) and about 6 cups chicken broth.  In separate kettle, melt 1 stick butter. Then add 1/2 tsp. pepper and 1/2 tsp salt. Gradually add 1 cup flour. Slowly whisk in 1 cup whipping cream and 2 cups of half and half. Cook until thickened. Add to soup. Then add arleady cooked 2 cups wild rice mix. Serve hot.  IT WAS AMAAAAZING. PLEASE TRY!!!

With a few minor changes this soup is outstanding!  I was sooo impressed.  I didn't have any dry white wine on hand so I took a risk and used burgandy instead.  I was not disappointed.  Cooked the chicken in burgandy and garlic which gave it great flavor.  Also added a small can of mushrooms and just over 1/2 c shredded baby carrots.  Added a splash more burgandy to the soup once I added the rice.  Wasn't as thick as I prefer so I added a bit of corn starch and viola!  It was perfect.  Thanks for a great recipe!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this for dinner last night and it was amazing. I followed the advice of other reviewers and made a few small changes to the recipe:  Softened 1 finely minced garlic clove and 1/4 c each finely minced onion, carrot, and celery in a small bit of olive oil before adding water, broth, and chicken; replaced cream with 1 can of full-fat evaporated milk + enough skim milk to make 2 cups of liquid; made roux with 6T butter and 1/2 c flour.  The recipe calls for a 4.5 ounce box of rice mix but I used a 6 ounce box of Near East Long Grain & Wild Rice Mix (original flavor) and it was perfect.  Next time (and there WILL be a next time), I will add 1/2 c finely minced sweet red pepper to the veggies before adding the liquids and chicken.

I've made this recipe several times now and each time I've made a small change and it has always turned out delicious. I made a pot once and ate nothing but this for 3 days. I have used heavy cream and then time substituted lactose free milk or regular milk. It tastes yummy either way. I always add a bit of chopped carrots, garlic, and because I love rice have added about 3/4 extra quick cook white rice. This is one of my regularly cooked dishes. When it's rainy or cold out I crave this. It is so simple and easy. I've cubed the chicken and shredded it. Personally I do like shredding 1 1/2 organic chicken breats the best. It is delicious with freshly baked bread. I highly recommend this dish!

text:
I've made this a few times and the first time I added carrots, celery, onion, and garlic per other reviewers' suggestions.  However, after making it again I only added carrots and celery sauteed in a little reduced fat margarine.  I used low fat Half 'n Half but 2% milk works just as well.  It was so much better.  This recipe DOES NOT need onion and definitely doesn't need garlic.  They add flavors that do not mesh well with this recipe and I'm a huge onion and garlic fan.  However the carrots and celery do.  Keep it simple!  Because I love wild rice I usually buy a small box and precook 1/2 cup of it before adding to the broth along with the fast cooking rice.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Amazing soup!!! I made 12 servings because I had 3 chicken breasts. I also took someone's advice about sauteing onions and garlic to add to the soup. During this step, I also added 2 cups of frozen mixed veggies to the saute and added all of that to the chicken and stock before the "add rice" step. Oh and making 12 servings also fit very well with the Uncle Ben's Long Grain & Wild Rice fast cook box that I used which was 6.2 ounce size. (I didn't see ANY version of wild rice that was 4.5 ounces). I cut back on the butter a bit using 1 stick (1/2 cup), and since it's what I had, I used 1% milk instead of the heavy cream. I was happy to see that adding veggies and reducing fat didn't take away from the soup.

Just as delicious as leftovers too! I froze two quart bags of the soup so I'll update once I know if it freezes well! **UPDATE** Freezes well!!! My daughter loved the soup the first time and after defrosting one of the quart freezer bags to use for her school lunch, she asked me WHAT was that DELICIOUS soup! She forgot she'd enjoyed this amazing soup at the beginning of the school year. Don't be afraid to make a big batch to freeze some of it because it DEFINITELY holds up.

userID:
4201988
Display Name:
OtherWorldlyDreamer
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is just amazing.  I've been making it for over a year now and made a few changes to suit our taste.  I saute a small diced onion in the pot with some butter, then add chicken and minced garlic and cook it seasoned with a little pepper and parsley.  Directly after that, without draining, I add 6 cups of water and 2 and 1/2 tsp of better than boullion (or boullion cubes, both work wonderfully in case anyone was wondering).  I bring it all to a boil and then add rice, turn off and cover as directed.  I make the cream-roux as directed except I use half and half (still comes out very rich and creamy).  Add it back to the pot, turn the pot back on and stir, add cayenne pepper (key in my opinion) a dash at a time to taste.  Then I add about a cup of frozen corn, cook at all on medium heat for about 10 mins (MUST cook at least ten mins or it will taste flour-y) and Oh MY!  It is awesome.

city:

None
text:
I have made this a few times now and use this recipe as my basis for my soup.  I finely chop the chicken.  To the broth I add finely diced garlic and onion as well as celery, fresh frozen peas, coarsely chopped mushrooms and thinly sliced peeled baby carrots.  I use half and half rather than heavy cream.  When "plated" it is garnished with fresh chopped parsely and a minimal amount of finely shredded cheese to show off the colors in the bowl.  A side of heated French Baugett bread is ideal for dipping in the thick, creamy soup.  I don't wait for it to get cold to have this soup.  It is one of my "go to" comfort foods - right up there with my thick and creamy homemade Mac and Cheese!

text:
Prepared as written with the following modifications. I used a large, chopped onion, 2 carrots, chopped, 2 ribs celery, chopped, sauteed in olive oil, that added only 10 minutes. Added 2 chicken breasts, raw, diced, until cooked, then added the broth, rice, etc. Recipe calls for 4 C broth 2 C water, I used 6 C broth. Also used Uncle Bens Original Recipe Wild Rice Mix, so I added 20 minutes to cook time there.All other ingredients/instructions followed exactly.
Amazing results, and I have never even considered a creamed soup in my life! A great winter dish, for sure.

Great soup for cold winter nights!  I sauteed 4 carrots, 1/2 onion, 3 celery stalks, and 2 garlic cloves, then cooked the soup according to the directions.  I had to add more water with the additional veggies (and a few chicken boulon cubes), but it made a more hearty and filling soup.

I also used canned chicken to speed up the process. This will become a regular meal throughout the winter!

text:
To start with this is a good outline recipe, but it really needed some modifications. I used the light and dark meat from a rotisserie chicken. I added 1 cup chopped broccoli, 1/2 cup shredded carrots and 1/3 cup diced onion. Needed a lot more depth of flavor so I added 1/2 tsp. garlic powder, 1/2 tsp. thyme, and 1/4 tsp. celery salt. After the changes this was fantastic and I would then give 5 stars.

text:
I made this soup tonight, and it's one of the better soups I've ever made. I did alter it though, based on taste. In my opinion, it was PERFECT. Started by dicing 1/2 cup of onions, 2 carrots and 2 celery. Sauteed them in 2 TB of butter until soft. Then added 6 cups of chicken broth (didn't use water). Added chicken, then 1 1/2 boxes of the rice (1 wasn't enough in my opinion). Made roux exactly as stated, then added 1/4 cup of white wine to the roux. It was PERFECT. 10 stars!

text:
Simple recipe, however I made a few modification.  Since I live in Minnesota, I bought my rice straight from the field. I know it takes a bit longer, however it is worth the wait.  I also used a rotisserie chicken from Sam's Club.  Great added flavor and quite a bit simpler.  Lastly, I used a couple of types of mushrooms (standard sliced buttons and sliced/cubed portabella mushrooms from again Sam's Club).  The longer it sits, the more the flavor is enhanced.

text:
This was exceptional! I followed suggestions from others and sauteed 1/2 cup each of celery, onion & carrots plus 8oz of sliced mushrooms in 2TB of butter, adding the chicken to cook a bit before putting the broth, water & rice in. The rice had the seasonings mixed in, which didn't matter at all.

For the roux, substituting 6 TB of butter, 1/2 cup flour & 1 1/2 cups skim milk was fine.

We're having leftover soup today for lunch! Thanks so much Stephanie!

text:
Thank you so much Stephanie for this recipe! This one made it into my "must make forever" file!

Notes to users who haven't tried it yet - you can do anything to this or nothing at all - I added sauteed onion/celery/carrots to the chicken/water/rice/broth mix - and since calories/fat are a concern in this house I used light butter and 1/2 and 1/2 and it still tastes very rich and creamy. Made it with buttermilk biscuits and it tasted like a chicken potpie. 

I had a bit of a time with the roux -flour/seasoning mix but I think that was because I used light butter - I just addd a little more. 

Again - a really fantastic cold day/comfort meal!!!

I did make some changes....BUT this is the BEST creamy chicken and rice soup I have EVER had!!!  First, I used the meat from a small savory rotisserie chicken.  I sauteed about a Tablespoon of freshly chopped Rosemary, a small onion (minced), a cup of shredded carrots, a Tablespoon of minced garlic, and 2 stalks of celery (minced) in about 2 Tablespoons of butter until tender, and added it to the stock with the chicken.  I followed the rest of the recipe exactly.....and served the soup in sourdough bread bowls....sigh, heaven!!!!!

text:
I am so glad I decided to try making this soup today! It was 12 degrees here this morning!  I read many of the reviews and made the following changes:  I first sauteed a few strips of bacon to flavor the pot then tossed the bacon and added the water, chicken broth and chicken as stated.  I used a rotisserie chicken.  I used the Uncle Ben's Wild and Long Grain Rice, Herb Roasted Chicken flavor. I melted the butter and added onion, celery and mushrooms before adding the flour mixture.  I also added the "healthy splash" of white wine at the end.  FANTASTIC FLAVOR!!!  I agree though that without the added veggies, there is not much to the soup. I will be making this again and probably will add carrots next time along with lots more mushrooms.

I did not have pre-cooked chicken so I added 2 breasts straight from the freezer to the broth and water mixture. They poached in the broth and worked fine. I also didn't buy the quick cook rice so added the amount of water called for on the box of rice to the pot. Used half and half instead of heavy cream and only 1/2 cup of flour. (The flour and butter amounts should be the same when you make a roux.) Turned out great! Next time I will make with the extra changes others have suggested.

text:
This is a fantastic soup recipe!!  I am giving it 5 stars based on how it turned out after making a few changes.  I took several suggestions from other reviewers and added the garlic, onion, celery and carrots.  I also used 6 cups of chicken broth instead of 2 c water and 4 cups broth.  I used the 6.2 oz size of the Uncle Bens fast cook rice (which I thought was a perfect size.  Just the right amount of rice and seasonings)  And last, I decreased the flour to 1/2 cup and it thickened up just fine.  Oh, I forgot ~ I used half and half instead of heavy cream.  This was a wonderful recipe!!  I have two boys (8 and 10) who are very picky and they both LOVED it!  I served this in bread bowls (recipe from this site) and it was perfect!  Definitely worth trying!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
A wonderful and divine soup. I baked an entire chicken and had half left over, so I decided to try out this soup with that. I used a box (4.3 oz) of rice-a-roni wild rice mix.  I also sauteed 1/2 c. or onion and a clove garlic in about 2 tbsp. butter, then added in 1/2 c. of both celery and carrot, thinly sliced, and continued sauteing until soft, around 5 min. or so. I then proceeded with the recipe. I used half-and-half instead of cream... no problems at all with that substitution, and less fat. The veggies add so much flavor and depth to the soup. If I could give more than 5 stars, I would!!! A very picky Aspie actually ATE dinner with us instead of snacking on fish sticks.

text:
This review is for the very modified version of the recipe as posted by naples31402. Changes made to the original recipe were that I didn't have a season packet with the wild rice, but rather sauteed maple turkey bacon, a big portabello mushroom, celery, garlic and onion and added it to the soup along with a little bit of dried parsley. I also wanted to add the white wine to bring out the flavors, but all I had was cheap champagne which still worked GREAT. Made this way, it was probably the BEST soup I've ever had. Awesome served with french bread. :)

I had no wild rice so used minute brown rice and my own seasonings (bay leaf, some garlic, onion, parsley). Also added veggies--carrots and celery.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Been making this for years...a few things that make this recipe easy peasy: saute onion, garlic and carrots in 2T of butter. Add 2 boxes of wild rice with seasoning packet. Follow liquid directions on boxes of rice using chicken broth instead of water. I don't mind using canned chicken in this recipe, so I add 2 10oz cans of chicken with the liquid. Boil it all according to rice directions (I go back and forth between quick cooking and normal rice). Once the time is up, add as much or as little half and half as you want. Don't bother thickening it if you cook it this way as you can control how thick/thin you want it. No extra cooking or mess either. I always end up adding salt and pepper just before serving. I really can't tell the difference cooking it like this. Perhaps even lots of other people figured this out...haven't read the reviews. However, the fam loves it and it's super quick and easy!

text:
I like this recipe, but I have made a lot of changes.  When I prepared this soup strictly as it's written, it was a little bland and I found it left me wanting, so I've gradually started doctoring it.  I saute up onions, celery, mushrooms, and green peas before I add chicken broth (I use all broth, no water), chicken, and rice.  Also, instead of heavy cream, I use fat free or low-fat milk - the roux will thicken the whole thing, so there's no need to use heavy cream.  Other than that, I use garlic powder and salt/pepper to taste and serve in a sourdough bread bowl (with a dash of Tabasco for the beau)! Yum! And this freezes well if you want to break the leftovers into individual serving sizes when you're in a squeeze!

text:
This soup was really good. I did make ours gluten free by eliminating the roux. I added a half onion and celery and a couple of small cloves of garlic and sauteed that in a drizzle of olive oil for about a minute or two. I also added about a tsp of bacon grease and then I added the stock, water, and shredded cooked chicken and let this all simmer together.  Meanwhile, I steamed the rice separately. When the rice was done I added it. I dissolved about 1/4c of corn starch in the milk and added that to the soup and brought it all to a boil and then turned it back down to simmer for 10 mins or so, stirring frequently. Very good! Thanks for sharing!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Took the advice of others.  I started by using 5 cans of chicken broth & 2 c of water.  I added about a 1/4 c diced celery & carrots & 1/2 tsp of Sage to the broth.  Instead of the chicken breasts I added the meat of a hot fully cooked grocery store rotisserie chicken (minus the skin...but I did add the wonderful juices from the bottom of the container).  After bringing to a boil I let it simmer for about 10-15 minutes.    I sauteed 1/2 cup of each (diced: onions, carrots, celery & mushrooms) in about a tbs of garlic butter.  I reduced thr broth to low and added the rice from a 6.2oz box of Uncle Ben's Long Grain & Wild Rice Fast Cook and covered for about 5 minutes or so.  Once cooked I added the sauteed veggies to the pot.  I used the same sautee pan with the flavoring on the bottom to make the roux.  I reduced the melted butter to 6 tbs. and added the seasoning packet as instructed. I only used approximately 1/3 c of flour with 1/2 tsp each of salt & pepper.  I used 16oz of half & half instead of the heavy cream so it may not have been as thick as some may prefer, but it was packed with all the flavor.  This was a meal in a bowl.  My husband, who can be extremely picky ate 4...yes FOUR, 4 bowls. It was a huge hit!!!  He loved it.  I would recommend this to everyone.

text:
this is a great, easy soup. i didn't have cream on hand, so i just used 1% milk and it was just fine. we have 3 to feed and we like leftovers and this doesn't make enough for that, so i would double the recipe if you're feeding more than 4. also, i only used about a 1/2 stick of butter and it's still so rich-tasting. i don't think it needed a full stick. i also added sliced carrots. i've made this 2-3 times now and it has a standing place in my rotating recipes. it's such a hearty, delicious soup--especially comforting  in the winter.

userID:
2922461
Display Name:
LouHoo in VA
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/288126.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely fabulous soup (with changes/additions that I made per several other reviewers' suggestions)!  To keep from dirtying so many pots/pans, I used one big pot to boil 3 seasoned chicken breasts in 2cups water (with 2T.EVOO) for 6-8 min.    Meanwhile, I coarsely chopped 1/2 onion, 2 ribs celery & sliced 3 carrots.  Remove chicken breasts from large pot & dice chicken when cooled (reserving cooking water/broth).    In smaller soup pan, cook 6.2oz. pkg. Uncle Ben's Wild Rice (reserving the seasoning package!) in the water you cooked the chicken breasts in (adds LOTS of flavor!).   Back in the big pot, I sauted the chopped onion, carrot & celery (& some mushrooms) in 2T. EVOO w/ 1t. minced garlic over medium-high heat, until veggies are tender.   Then stir in the seasoning pkg. from the rice until bubbly.  Add 1T. butter at a time & 1T. flour at a time until you have a nice roux, stirring into the veggies (probably only need 3-4 T. of each).  Reduce heat to medium-low & gradually add 2cups 2% Milk & a 14oz.can of chic.broth, stirring until smooth & creamy.  (Optional: add 1/3 cup white wine).  Add chopped chicken & rice to big pot. Simmer for 10 minutes until smooth & rich & heated through.  Wow!!!

text:
Simple and delicious! The only reason I didn't give this 5 stars is because it is too rich for my taste if made with the specified amounts of butter & heavy cream. I used 1 tbsp. of butter and substituted 2% milk. Also used regular wild rice (not quick cooking). The soup turned out great! This is an extremely easy recipe, especially with a rotisserie chicken! Thanks for a keeper!

userID:

Display Name:
FAMILYJEANS
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/146454.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent soup recipe!  I did make some changes though (as it looks like most people did).  The thought of that much butter and cream made me look for some elastic waist pants.  :oP  I used 2 cans of chicken broth with the other ingredients (including Uncle Ben's Fast Cook Wild Rice), omitted the salt (there's enough in there already), and omitted the flour, butter and cream.  I used a can of evaporated milk (PET milk) with about 1/3 cup cornstarch along with a dash of onion powder.  Don't overstir after adding the cornstarch or it will thin out (cornstarch also doesn't freeze well, so use flour in this recipe if you plan on freezing leftovers).  Using the cornstarch and evaporated milk cut WAY down on calories and fat without sacrificing taste.  Next time I may throw some potato flakes in too for added thickness.  All of us enjoyed this recipe - it'll be going in our regular file.  :o)

country:
None
text:
This was a delicious soup!  I grabbed the wild rice soup packet that was NOT quick cooking and it was fine.  I sauteed chopped onion, carrot, and garlic for a few minutes and then added the broth, water, and chicken (from a roasted chicken purchased at the supermarket).  Once it came to a boil, I added the rice mix and turned the stove to low and covered for 20 minutes.  Then I added the flour mixture.  I used 1% milk and 6 T. butter and 1/2 c. flour and it came out great.  This recipe is versatile.  I tried to use less butter but needed more to mix with the flour.  This was great and I will definately make again!

I have made this multiple times now and each time it has been great. I served this at Christmas for about 20 people.  It was very popular with adults and kids.

I started with chopped onions, carrots and celery like previous reviewers.

I also used:

- 1% milk instead of heavy cream.

- Uncle Ben's Whole Grain & Wild Rice, Mushroom Recipe.

- 100% whole wheat flour.

I added additional salt & pepper before serving.

This will definitely be something I make again and again.  It scales beautifully to feed a crowd.

text:
This is a nice way to use up leftovers.  I used a wild rice mixture without the flavour packet, and I didn't have heavy cream, so I used half & half and it was fine.  For more flavour I started with a mirepoix (sauted onion, carrot and celery), then made the roux.  I also added fresh garlic.  I will make this again.

text:
This recipe is fabulous and I've made this several times.  I do make ajustments like other members have mentioned and it is just delicious.( I try to cut down on fat and calories.)
  I always add the following:
    Carrots, celery and fresh mushrooms( I cook this in the broth, then add the rice.)
I also use a little bit of skim milk instead of cream  and it is still good.  Although I made it for a family gathering and used whole milk and it was even better. I had to give this recipe to several people.
I try not to use as much butter or flour to cut down on calories.
I also use Uncle Ben's Long Grain & Wild Rice. I love the seasoning.
   I really don't think you can go wrong with this recipe.  Thank you for this recipe.
  Enjoy!

text:
Really delicious!  My whole family enjoyed this.  To get some veggies into all of us, I sauteed some finely chopped celery and carrots and added them in with the broth mixture.  Also, just a few minutes before this was done, I dumped in some frozen corn- maybe 1 1/2 cups or so.  I used 1% milk since it was what I had, and it still made an incredibly thick and creamy soup.  I consider myself a pretty good cook, but this recipe made me look like a pro!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this soup several times & everyone who tries it....loves it (even my kids!).  I've cooked the chicken while making the soup & added the chicken at the end - same great result & it saved on prep time.  I've cut calories & carbs by using light butter, half & half (instead of heavy cream), and fat free/low carb chicken broth.  Also, regular rice (not quick cook) works fine, just let it cook/simmer a little longer.  While cooking, sometimes the soup gets a little thicker than I prefer - by adding milk, water, or more broth - - still tastes wonderful!   I have passed this recipe on to several people - highly recommend!

text:
Cover picture is mis-leading as the recipe does not include carrots.
Made this last night for the second time with some home canned chicken breast that we mixed in Montreal Steak Seasoning in several of the jars....and that is what I used.
I also cut up about a cup of carrot "coins" and cooked them in water until they were tender. I also added a large can of mushrooms. I reserved all of the liquid and used for my water.
I added these two ingredients just before I added the roux mixture.
Great winter soup recipe and with my changes a new favorite.
Might add.....was directed to this recipe from our Echo Dot Alexa when I asked her for a canned chicken recipe. ??

text:
This soup was phenomenal! But I would HIGHLY recommend doing as other reviewers have suggested, which is to  sauté some onion, celery, garlic, and carrots to place in the soup, and boil a couple of fresh chicken breasts with a little S&P, onion and garlic powder. It’s super quick and easy to do this, and it will give you fresh unprocessed chicken stock for your soup with some extra to freeze for later!

This was a really good dish. I made it on a snow day which was perfect for the occassion. I took someone else's advice on the thickness because it looked a bit thick in the  video. So I cut the flour to 1/2 cup and the butter to 6 tbs and that was just right. I substituted milk for the heavy cream and  also took someone else's suggestion and added some carrots, celery, and onion. This is a recipe I will definitely make over and over again.

This was so delicious that I sent the recipe to my son and daughter-in-law to try. I followed the recipe but may have used more chicken than called for in the recipe so I could use up a leftover.  I did add a couple grated carrots and some thinly sliced celery, mainly for color. I only used chicken broth and no water. I also used 2cups of half and half for the heavy cream.  I will be making this again and again. After Thanksgiving I’ll try it using turkey. I bet that will be delicious too. Thanks for this keeper! text:
This is an excellent base recipe for soup.  Per other reviewers suggestions, I sautéed a little garlic, onions, celery and carrots to give the soup a bit more body and flavor.  I also used a cup of heavy cream and a cup of skim milk just to lighten it a tad with a half cup of flour.  That worked out fine.  I also used a 7 ounce box of Uncle Ben's long grain and wild rice because I could not find a 4.3 ounce box.  To get shredded chicken, I boiled two chicken breasts in 2 cups of chicken broth for about an hour.  I also added a bay leaf to the broth, and included the broth in the soup when done boiling the chicken.  The flavor was great.  I will definitely make this again.

Display Name:
Amy Secretan

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/20.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my goodness this soup is SO delicious. I followed other reviewers suggestions and added diced celery and carrots (it truly would be fine without the veggies, but they really make it a meal), sauteed over medium heat for about 5 minutes with a little butter. I did this first in the stock pot, and then added the broth and chicken on top of the sauteed veggies and let all that come to a boil, that way your broth has some depth when you add the rice, and your veggies have time to cook. I also reduced the flour but I didn't measure it out, I just added until the butter/seasoning mix was no longer taking in the flour, which was significantly less than what was called for. I also used milk instead of cream, turned out just fine! I really loved the flavor, it was satisfying without tasting too salty. The leftovers (which I ate for the next TWO days...) were outstanding, the flavor just gets better with time. Such a great soup, can't wait to make this again on cold winter nights!

city:

country:
None
text:
This is my favorite soup. EVER. I make this at least twice a month. It is also my favorite thing to bring to sick friends, friends with new babies, it is that good and yummy and I ALWAYS double the recipe. It is better than a Panera soup. SO GOOD!
I make a few modifications as other reviews have suggested. This is for the original soup measurements. 
First I poach my 2 chicken breasts in 3 cups water, 4 cups chicken broth. (I add more water due to the extra veggies) I add 1 cup diced carrots and 1 cup diced celery to the poaching liquid and I also add salt, pepper and a bay leaf. Once poached I remove the floating chicken fat and bay leaf and then add the rice. Now I have a more flavorful broth. I use Rice A Roni Long Grain and Wild Rice. When making the roux I use half and half. Really doesn't make any flavor difference with the heavy cream. NOTES: don't burn the roux and be sure to let it simmer to thicken - mistakes I have made.
This soup is actually better the next day. I add chicken broth when reheating.

text:
I too started with browning onion, celery, carrots and garlic. Rather than make my roux later and blend, I chose to start my veggies in 6 tablespoons of butter, and after 5 minutes, added my 1/2 cup off flour before adding my 1 1/2 cup of plain wild rice and 4 cups of Better Than Boullion Chicken broth (I am not a fan of packaged seasoned rice), brought it to a boil, than simmer for ~50 minutes. At the end I added 1 cup of half-n-half and 1 cup of skim milk. Seasoned with coasher salt and pepper. It turned out creamy and delicious. Next time I might experiment with herbs like Thyme or Rosemary.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Modified this recipe by sautéing 1 sweet onion, 1 C. chopped baby carrots, 1 C. chopped celery, and 1 small can sliced mushrooms in 2 tbs butter. Added 3-14.5 oz cans chicken broth and 4.5 oz water (to equal 6 cups liquid) and chopped rotisserie chicken. Brought to a boil, then added 1 pkg white & wild rice (NOT fast cook), reduced heat to med-low, and cooked for 20 min. Made roux per recipe, whisked into soup, and cooked an additional 10 min. Added more salt halfway through end cooking. Served with French bread. So good.

text:
Mmmmm, mmmmm good! We just finished enjoying this delicious hardy soup. We went for a late afternoon walk in 30 degree weather and the soup warmed us right up!  Like others, we cut back on the flour, used about 1/4 cup and used half and half.  Sautéed onions, carrots and celery in butter with a dash of garlic powder before adding flour.  Also added a couple of pinches of season salt to suit our tastes.  The soup is definitely a keeper, plan to make it for family visitors during the holidays. Thanks so much for the recipe, yum!

text:
I made one substitution (half and half for the heavy cream) but did the rest as written.  Tasted it, found it to be too salty so I added more 1/2 & 1/2.  Everyone seemed to enjoy it, next time I'll add celery and carrots, use 3/4 of the seasoning packet, and perhaps less flour in the roux since it thickened up A LOT.  And that was with the additional cream I added!  With a few tweaks it'd be even a notch higher than the good soup it is.

Took the advice of other reviewers and added celery, carrots, onion, and garlic. Cooked in a broth for about 45 min with bay leaves before adding the rice and chicken. Used half n half and skim milk to cut down on calories a little. Still good consistency and a hearty meal. Think I would have preferred cubing the chicken instead of shredding but overall a very satisfying meal. Added fresh baked bread on the side for dipping to complete the dish.

text:
The only reason I'm not giving this 5 stars is because it seems to be missing something flavor-wise and I'm not sure if it's the recipe's fault or mine... I used 6.5 cups of homemade chicken stock (omitting the  water), included the veggies as suggested in the other reviews (carrots, celery, onions, garlic), and used 4 tablespoons each of brown rice flour (gluten-free) and butter and about 1.5 cups of half-and-half. I also added an extra 1/3 cup of white rice. Looking at the reviews I'm now wondering whether I picked the wrong prepackaged wild rice mix. I used Near East brand; maybe I should have used Uncle Ben's instead? Anyway, in every other way the soup is perfect: creamy and hearty.

dateLastModified:
2014-02-06T10:42:49.54
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1313505
Display Name:
Caryl
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
94
favoritesCount:
1899
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2612747.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is our favorite soup.  My kids love it!  I always just cut up 2 chicken breasts into bite size pieces and brown them in olive oil, S&P.  When that is done I put the chicken in foil and set aside.  I add 2-3 TBSP of butter to the pot and sauté 1 minced onion, 2 garlic cloves(minced), 2 stalks of celery (diced) and 1/3 c. of minced carrots and S&P.  Once softened, I add the flour and mix it until the veges are coated.  I add the chicken stock and about 3 cups of white rice and about 1 tsp of thyme.  Then I add the water & milk (instead of heavy cream-it still comes out thick & creamy!).  Cook until thickened about 10 minutes and then I add the chicken.  The best!

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2368134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was tasty at the first cup, or just made. However, it was so rich I just could not eat one more cup or bowl, or the leftovers, which I am really dependent on. The rice packet had a lot of sodium. So, I cut the 1/2 tsp of salt to 1/4 tsp. I also mixed up some broth using broth paste to taste to reduce the saltiness further. For the heavy cream I used half and half, as I read in some of the reviews, and for the butter I used butter with olive oil to cut the cholesterol back some. The soup was still very thick with those changes. I see this soup recommended all of the time, so it appears to be popular. I think, I just may prefer soups made more with vegetable purees or a little less heavy.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-12-12T12:04:15.107
helpfulCount:
1

2267383

I will add that I do agree with some reviewers - the soup is very rich. I think next time I will try using half and half instead of heavy cream. Although my husband and 5 yr old daughter absolutely loved as is.

text:
Wild rice goes well with creamy chicken soup.  Based on the other reviews, I made following modification similar to the other reviewers: sautéed both 1/2 cup of carrot and celery, 1 cup of onion (make the soup a bit more sweeter), and garlic.  Changed from heavy cream to skim milk, 6 spoon of butter instead of 8, smaller amount of salt & pepper, used Minnesota wild rice.  My version is, I suppose (as I didn't make the original version), sweeter with generous amount of onion, less salty (or milder flavor).  Would go well with salmon & veggie broth, instead of chicken, perhaps.  Had this soup with home made white bread.  Yum!

text:
I made this soup the first time as written and LOVED it!  I have made it several times since and have made a couple of changes and LOVE, LOVE, LOVE it still!  The changes I made were to first, use only chicken stock (no water), I also saute about 3/4 of a cup each of onion, carrot and celery (I think those always make a soup better plus I like the color of the carrots!) while the stock and chicken are coming to a boil. Because of the addition of those three items, I did increase the chicken broth by one cup.  This soup no matter how you make it is a sure fire winner!!!

I absolutely LOVE this recipe, as did my guests.  I added a few handfuls of chopped celery, carrots and mushrooms as well as a small diced yellow onion to make the soup more hearty and to add a little crunch (add more or less of each veggie according to your preference).  My sister-in-law said it was the best she'd ever had.  I'm from Minnesota, so we know our wild rice soup - and I think I have to agree with my sister-in-law.  It's like a warm, buttery Ritz cracker in your mouth, BUT BETTER!  My brother and sister-in-law have already requested it again (many times, actually) and I plan to make it for them soon as a series of dinners I'll be bringing over to their house now that they're brand new parents!  A TOTAL KEEPER!

text:
I am going to give this 5 stars but I do saute onions, celery and carrot to add to the soup to create a more hearty and substantial meal. I have made this soup many times, and it's at least as good as the chicken and wild rice soup at Panera, which is fabulous. The other modification consistently is using skim milk instead of heavy cream. Since you are using a thickening method anyway, it really doesn't take anything away from this fantastic soup.

Display Name:
afraser

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is GREAT! My 3 young daughters (9, 6, 2)and husband gobbled up the entire pot. Even my picky 6-year-old asked for more, and said I could pack it for lunch in her thermos. This is the kid that has eaten only a PB & J for lunch every day at school. Anyhow, I did a few adjustments as others suggessted.....saute some onion, carrots, celery & garlic in olive oil 1st. Then proceed to follow directions. I also cut back on the butter, used only 4 Tbsp or less. Also used less flour, 1/2 cup. Last alteration was to use milk versus heavy cream. At the very end of the cooking time, I wanted a little thicker consistency so I mixed some flour with water to make a liquidy paste and added it to the soup. I added it on this end of the recipe intead of in the middle to save on adding more butter. I will definitely be making this for years to come, and givng the recipe to others.

This soup was amazing!! All the reviews were right -- this soup was perfect on a nice cold and gray kind of day. Like most others, I added some garlic, celery and carrots for a little flavor, and a little white wine in the chicken broth. Thanks for the great recipe, I will DEF be making this a lot more during the winter.

Display Name:
Shannon

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2787858.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didnt necessarily like what I considered to be extra steps to this recipe, so to make it as "one-pot" as possible, I changed things a bit. I almost feel guilty reviewing this recipe, since I deviated from the original steps, but since the majority of the other 1100+ reviewers also switched things up, I figured my review wouldn't be too far off. I also used the 1/2 c onions/carrots/celery combo. I also added spices to my liking: garlic & onion powders, parsley, and a good shake of Tony Chachere's. I imagine a pretty bland soup otherwise! Used Uncle Ben's Mushroom Wild Rice, which was great, however the seasoning packet turned the soup brown! No matter, as the flavor was fantastic! Used 1 c 2%  milk and 1 c half & half. Even making my own roux, I still wanted a heartier soup, so added a cornstarch slurry until it was my desired consistency. Oh, and I also used a whole package of boneless, skinless chicken thighs which I'd pre-cooked/shredded in my crockpot earlier in the day. For my needs, this was a great soup base. I can't wait to make this again!

text:
Update: 01/2019 - I haven't made this in awhile and this was just as good as I remembered!  So rich & creamy.  I put it together and put a lid on the pot and let it simmer for a few hours before dinnertime.  I do 1/2 cup each of celery, onion, and carrot.  I  might do a little more next time.  I froze the leftovers for lunch soon.

Original review: OUTSTANDING!  Delicious.  I believe previous comments said this was a restaurant quality soup, and I would have to agree.  I also took advice from comments, and added a little carrot, celery and onion.  Also, I used instant wild rice soup, but not the kind w/ the seasoning packet - and it turned out fine.  Very hearty and filling soup.  Served w/ garlic breadsticks.

So the first time I made this I "slow cooker"-ized it. I also changed the seasonings because I didnt have a box of the rice. It was good, and I knew it would be worth making again. This time I made it EXACTLY as per the recipe, the only exception being I used whole milk instead of cream and I added a shredded carrot. Holy cow it is so much better this way! My 2 year old is gobbling it up as I am typing this. This soup is soooooo creamy, delicious, and incredibly easy to make. This will become one of our winter favorites for sure. Make this and do NOT deviate from the recipe. You will NOT be sorry. P.S. My 2 year old just said "Mommy more?" Yep...if that doesnt say winner I dont know what does.

None
country:
None
text:
I really like this recipe.  I followed it almost exactly and I was pleasantly suprised.  My changes:  sauted onions, minced garlic (4 garlic cloves), celery and carrots in butter until tender.  Used whole milk instead of heavy cream.  Another note, 2 chicken breasts are definitely needed for this recipe because it makes quite a bit of soup.  Also, don't add the chicken until the very end, i.e. after the soup has cooked for 10 to 15 minutes with the cream/milk roux.  As a final touch, add 1/2-3/4 tsp of salt in addition to the amount listed in the recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good, my favorite soup has always been cream of chicken and rice at the restraunts. I took the advice of the others, and added 1/2 cup chopped celery and 1/2 cup of carrots and white onion and minced garlic in 2 tbsp olive oil. I also added chicken granuals to the broth for extra flavor,And used 1/2 cup white wine, used 1 chopped up already cooked chicken breast, and used orzo instead of.rice, because we didn't have rice, but its the closest thing to it. 

For the cream I used 1/2 cup flour and 6 tbsp butter, added 1 cup fat free half and half, 1 cup skim milk and it still came out thick. 

After adding cream mix to the broth, I added some final touches of few dashes of onion powder, garlic powder and some dries basil. Let.simmer.on.low.heat for a half hour, and put it in the fridge overnight.
It was pretty thick the next day so added some skim milk when I.was.reheating it. 
Excellent!! Even my dad loved it, and he's not a big soup eater. Def will make this way again!!!

False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/594818.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My variation was absolutely fabulous. After reading the reviews, I made several revisions to the recipe. I used 3 cans of chicken broth, 2 cups of water (saved from boiling my chicken), 2 c. 1/2 & 1/2, a 6 oz. box of Uncle Ben's Wild and Long rice in original flavor, a cup of chopped celery, 1/2 c. julienned carrots and a small onion, chopped. I also cut up into small chunks a pound of bacon, fried & drained it then used the leftover grease to fry the veggies along with some minced garlic (2 cloves). I drained the veggie mix then followed the directions for the recipe using the variations to parts as listed above. Oh yeah, I only used 1/2 c. of flour too. After I combined everything, I poured about a cup of Chardonnay wine into it. I served it with some cheese bread and even my picky grandchildren ate it. It was delicious!

Delicious!!  I took the advice of other reviewers and added 1/2 cup each carrots, celery, onion, and 2 cloves of garlic.  I also added mushrooms just for personal preference. But a MUST is to add frozen sweetlet peas to the soup right before serving ... they thaw but still stay nice and crunchy!  Adds a nice texture to the soup.  Awesome recipe ... thanks for sharing!

text:
So tasty! Although I did change mine up. Added 1 cup chopped carrots, one cup chopped celery, two garlic cloves minced and 1/2 cup onion,sauted that in some smart balance then added it to the soup. I used 4 cups of chicken stock and 3 cans of chicken broth..used 3/4 of a roasted chicken which I cooked in with the broth for a while before adding the veggies. Then I proceded to make the roux with 1 cup of skim milk, 1 cup of light cream..used Brummel & Brown (3 tablespoons) and the rest regular butter to reduce the fat..WOW the result with the wild rice is incredible THANKS for this very tasty soup.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/652266.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW!  Hubby said to give it even more than 5 stars!  This is an excellent recipe.  I boiled 2 chicken breasts and 1 leg quarter with some chopped onions, then about 20 minutes before that was ready, I added about 2 cups each of sliced carrots and celery.  When I removed the chicken to shred and de-bone I strained 6 cups of the liquid off into a measuring bowl and added 4 chicken boullion cubes.  I would have drained off the rest down the sink, or added water as needed but just so happens it was almost exactly 6 cups of liquid!  I poured all that back in the pot with the veggies, added the shredded chicken and rice, then proceeded with the roux.  I left out the salt since I used boullion and I added some white cooking wine (about 1/4 cup) and about 2 teaspoons of garlic powder toward the end of the cooking time.  This is one of the best things I've ever made... It kind of reminds me of the creamy soup you get at the Dixie Stampede dinner theatre!  Simply delicious!

text:
Simple and easy. I use the long grain wild rice because i only had a package or Knorr Cajun style with red peppers instant mix rice. So i skipped the seasonings part went straight to the rouge and added the rice+seasons in step one Turned into a nice Cajun chicken and rice soup with a little spice from the red peppers. A little more pepper to up the spice, and a dash of rosemary in your personal bowl is a nice sweet touch.

I added celery, mushrooms, onions, garlic and carrots to this soup.  I used 1 cup heavy cream and 1 cup 1% milk.  I used the left over turkey from Christmas dinner - the soup came out very good.  The reason I didn't give it 5 stars is: I don't think the 1 box of rice was enough - I could hardly tell that it had rice and the second reason - I felt that the flavor was a little bland - even though our turkey was super flavorful.  I will make this recipe again - adding a little more seasonings and a second box of rice.

I followed others instructions adding carrots, celery, onions, a little garlic, decreasing butter to 6T, flour to 1/2c, and using milk instead of heavy cream.  I altered the recipe by using turkey and adding all broth (6c), having boiled the bones of the turkey cooked for Thanksgiving. I changed up the recipe by putting it in the crockpot to cook all day (I did not saute veggies, smelled soo good), I added two cups of water half way through (would have used broth but was frozen).  I find ther seems to be some flavor lacking but cannot put my finger on what it is.

text:
This is the most awesome soup i have ever had. I first tasted chicken and wild rice soup at my bingo hall and decided i needed to learn to make it. I did make a few adjustments. I first cut up celery, carrots , garlic and a small onion and sauteed them in some olive oil then i added the broth but only put as much water for the rice as the package directions stated i also could only find the uncle bens 6.5 oz.. i either use an already roasted chicken from the deli or i get some chicken breast and roast them in the oven. i add more chicken then it calls for and use a mixture of heavy cream and 1% milk. it turns out so thick and creamy its like heaven

text:
I made this soup to go with beer bread and it was wonderful. I changed it just a little because I just tend to do that when I am making any food. I cooked 4 chicken breasts in 6 cups of water to make the chicken broth and then shredded the chicken. As that was boiling I added spices and 1 1/2 cups of rice and let it cook until the rice was done. By this point I had already made the creamy sauce portion and put that in a crockpot on warm while the chicken and rice was finishing. I mixed everything in the crockpot and then went to work. Also Dill is a nice addition to this soup. Very good. Will definetly make again.

text:
This recipe is FANTASTIC! A major hit at my house- I'm the soup-lover, the one who'll opt to eat soup on a hot summer day, but my husband who is a titch harder to please absolutely loves this soup. I did make a few changes, however. The recipe calls for 1/2 c butter and 2 c heavy cream. I cut the butter down to 1/4 and use half and half, then use fat free cream of chicken soup to get some of that creaminess back. I also add carrots, onions, and celery to get some rich veggie flavors. This recipe is to die for if you're a soup-enthusiast like me, and  filling, hearty, and comforting for those who have not yet converted. :-) I also served these in warm bread bowls... so yummy!

text:
Since I modified this quite a bit, this review is based on the following changes:   Used a crock pot - cooked chicken breasts with water and broth for about 3 hours on high until chicken was tender enough to shred. Prepared the cream as directed but used 1/2 cup flour and fat free 1/2 and 1/2 in place of heavy cream.   Sauteed about 1 cup of carrots, 5 stalks celery, 1/2 Spanish onion and 1 1/2 Tbsp crushed garlic in olive oil until vegetables were soft.   Added vegetables and cream mixture. Didn't seem very thick and the pepper was overwhelming so I tamed it by adding about 8oz. reduced fat cream cheese.  Cooked on high for about another hour.  What a nice flavor and SO creamy and rich!  Highly recommend trying this.  Pretty good overall.  Maybe nest time I will try as submitted and not with the crock.

country:
None
text:
Great recipe, thick and filling. Made it as is the first time, was able to lighten it up the second time by mixing the flour with a cup of the broth instead of making a roux and adding fat free half and half instead of the heavy cream.  At the end of cooking, I added a tablespoon of whipped butter just to make it a little richer. These changes made the soup a reasonable weight watchers points+ value as calculated on etools. I added a lot of pepper. Would benefit from a little thyme. I like mushrooms, but my family doesn't so I added some to my bowl and let the heat of the soup "cook" the mushrooms. Reheats well in the microwave.

text:
I added the 2 cups uncooked rice, 1/2 cup finely chopped celery, carrots, onion, 1/2 lb mushrooms, (bacon) salt, 1/2 tsp parsley, ground black pepper, poultry seasoning and some garlic to the crock pot. Add 6 cups chix broth (no water), cook on low 8 hrs.
Melt butter in a large saucepan over medium heat. Stir in the Then add the flour and stir well. (roux) Gradually pour into soup mixture  stirring constantly, until all has been added. 
serve with warm bread or dinner rolls - yum!

(I omitted chix, may add chix sometimes.)

text:
I've made this recipe many times, and I just love it!  I wanted to add my healthier version though- first, I cook the rice as directed in a medium pan (I use 6 oz. Uncle Ben's).  Then, I melt 1/4 cup butter, whisk in 1/4 cup flour, 2 cups of milk (typically skim), 2 cups chicken broth, salt & pepper, and cook to thicken.  I add the cooked rice & chicken, and heat through.  This is my favorite soup!
