I used leftover rice we had in the fridge, so because that meant I didn't have a packet of seasonings, I just added curry, thyme, and extra salt to the flour/spice mixture.  Also, because the rice was already cooked, I first threw in some chopped celery and frozen vegetables, let them cook a while, and then added the rice.  Milk worked just fine instead of cream, too.  I usually don't like to change a recipe so much the first time I make it, but I didn't have time to run to the store first.  It was good even with my changes!

How about the 266 calorie/ 9 gr Fat per serving version! :) I substituted Fat Free Half and Half for the heavy cream and Smart Balance instead of butter. text:
AWESOME, my son had his wisdom teeth pulled & needed something soft to eat, he is a picky eater & first we got him Panera's soup and he liked it, so instead of paying $4 for a small cup again we made this and he LOVED it so much that we made a second batch. I used whole milk instead of heavy cream and thickened it up a little with some corn starch, it came out very creamy and thick. The second time I used 2 % milk and he couldn't tell the difference so we saved calories and fat once again. This is by far superior to Panera's expensive soup and goes excellent with some fresh bread. Cheap to make and makes a good amount. Also I used canned chicken in place of chicken breasts which is nicely shredded already and has the perfect texture for this type of soup, I just strain and rinse it in a colander. I wouldn't bother with the chicken breast halves since the canned chicken works so well.

text:
An easy, comforting soup, but it needs some lightening up, a little more flavor and veggies.  I've made this a few times, and I add additional seasonings: oregano, parsley, thyme, and poultry seasoning.  I also add onion, celery, and mushrooms.  Save yourself some calories by using just 5 T butter, 1/2 c. flour, and skim milk...it gets plenty thick.  In fact, the next day, the soup is so thick, that it needs to be thinned with milk.

text:
This recipe was absolutely amazing. I made a few minor changes to kick up the flavor a bit. Instead if the 2 cups water 4 cups chicken broth. I did 7 cups water with 4 tsp of chicken bouillon granules. I added 1/2 cup onion, 1/2 celery, a clove of garlic and cut up about 12 baby carrots being I didn't have any regular sized carrots. I then took a tsp of butter and added my veggies into that sauteeing them for about 10 minutes or until onions were translucent. I added my veggies into the broth and chicken mixture along with  1/2 tsp of crushed rosemary, 1/2 tsp ground thyme and a sprinking of white pepper. The last addition to the recipe I made was a 1/2 cup white cooking wine...YUM!! This dish was amazing and very, very flavorful. I will definitely be making this one again soon.

text:
I have made this recipe twice.  I love the flavor of it!  The first time I made it, I let the roux brown just a little, which changed the overall color of the soup.  The second time I made it, I kept careful watch over the roux and did not let it brown.  The result was a beautiful creamy soup.  This recipe will definitely remain in my recipe box and used as a staple, especially during the winter months!

This was quick and easy to make!  I did use all chicken broth instead of the 2 c. water and I added a little more seasoning from another packet (thoroughly mixing b/4 using) that I had left over from another recipe plus a little garlic powder.  I will say that it was a little "floury" tasting so I think that I will divide the flour w/ half being cornstarch next time.  I also used only 1 c. of cream and 1 c. of milk to cut down on the richness.  It was stupendous!

text:
This soup is pretty good overall. I, like other reviewers, made several modifications when making this, though: Instead of using 2 cups of heavy cream, I used only 1; I added carrots, celery, mushrooms, and a few cloves of garlic (although I'll use less garlic in the future); I added about a 1/2 cup of sharp cheddar cheese as well. After adding those ingredients, I found the soup to be a tiny bit bland (although wonderfully creamy and rich), so I put several extra grinds of salt in. Good stuff!

Display Name:
Cindy in Pensacola

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2040898.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this relatively non-fat and it was still a hit with my picky, picky husband who doesn't like me to try anything "new".  Here's what I did.  I used Rice-a-Roni Long Grain & Wild Rice mix and cooked just the rice as directed on the package.  I mixed the seasoning packet in another pot with 2 T of 50% reduced fat margarine and then the 3/4 cup of seasoned flour.  Of course it was very, very dry but I poured in about 1 cup of chicken broth and that smoothed it out.  I then added about 3 cups of skim milk.  Made for a nice thick "roux".  I aslo used 2 of the Minute Rice Ready to Eat long grain & wild rice packs to make it a bit more ricey since this makes a TON of soup.  All those changes but followed the rest of the directions.  When I tasted it, it was sorely lacking in flavor.  I added some garlic powder, more pepper, and some cajun spice.  This made it more palatable and brought it to a 4.  I don't think my no-fat ingredients were the problem.. I just feel that it needed more umppphhhh.  That's my two cents.

text:
It's very easy to see why this one made it into allrecipes Soup Top 20. Thanks, Stephanie. I did make a few modifications based on what I had on hand so I didn't have to make a trip to the store:  1)used instant rice, 2) used the seasoning packet from a package of Chicken Ramen Noodles, 3) used 1 cup 1% milk and 1 cup cream instead of two cups cream, 4) per another reviewer, sauteed 1/2 cup of diced sweet onion and 1/2 cup diced celery in the butter, before making the roux, and, 5) lightly salted and peppered the chicken. The soup was an amazing restaurant quality. My wife and I both loved it and will definitely make it again.

text:
Yummy! Thank you CrdsGrl for sharing this recipe - and Carrie for her review and a few healthier alternatives.   First, to make it more healthy: sautee garlic, olive oil, 2 sliced celery ribs. Sauteed until softened... Then add sodium free broth, water, dried shitaki mushrooms, rice and chicken (I added a package that I needed to use up [1 1/2 pounds].) In the separate pan, melt 5 Tb. salt-free butter, add the salt/pepper, seasoning packet, 1/2 c. all purpose flour (my kitchen only has gluten-free), 2 cups fat free half and half.   I had 1 Tb cream cheese with minced mushroom from another dish that I needed to use up - which I added. In the future, when making this again - I would add more rice. Happy Cooking everyone!

text:
Very good!  I did add bacon and used a roasted chicken for ease.  My issue with this is that it is called 'chicken and WILD RICE soup'.  Not 'chicken, long grain, and wild rice soup'.  Point being that those boxed rice mixes have so little wild rice that it almost is silly to even mention it.  This would be a 5 if it were all wild rice.  You would think this would an easy fix however, I think that the seasoning packet from the long grain and wild rice just about made the dish so I wouldn't exactly swap the boxed stuff with wild rice.

text:
I always look for big numbers and 5 stars.  This recipes caught my eye but all of the changes to the recipe had me bewildered.  I took a little from many of the comments and did this:  sauted carrots, onions, & garlic in olive oil.  Added 6 cups of chicken broth & therefore omitted the water.  Added the rice & chicken & simmered for 10 mins.  Made the roux with 1/4 c butter, season packet, & 1/4 c flour.  Used 2 c whole milk.  Then added it to soup and simmered for another 15 mins.  Turned out great!

text:
Delicious, thick, and creamy! I baked my own boneless chicken breasts with plenty of pepper, basil, and thyme which added plenty good flavor. Used whole milk in lieu of the heavy cream. I didn't use the seasoning packet that came with the rice. Used only 1/2 cup flour and 6 TBSP butter. Sautéed chopped onion, celery, and garlic and added to the soup. I think peas would also be a good addition. Next time I'll need to remember to pick up a nice crusty bread at local bakery. I will certainly make this again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave this an Average Rating, or 3 stars, because the flavor was pretty good, but overall not a very good cream of chicken soup recipe.  First, liquid should be added to the roux, never the other way around as this recipe instructs (because lumps occur).  Best would be to boil the stock/water mixture, place in a bowl and put the rice in at that time and cover.  Use the original pan to make the roux, and add the stock back in small amounts to the pan at that time.  You will have much smoother soup.  I added celery, onion and garlic as others did.  I would omit the garlic next time as cream of chicken soup doesn't normally have this.  I also added a tsp of MSG which brings the flavors together well.  UPDATE: I tried this again with the above changes, and I have to say, it was GREAT!

text:
This was delish! I did make some minor adjustments though: I roasted a turkey earlier this week so i used turkey instead of chicken. I didn't have quick cooking wild rice on hand so i used regular (which was fine but next time i'll use quick cook just to make it faster) also my seasoning packet had an additional grain in it so i just tossed it in the soup instead of making the roux with it. Once I was done my soup was WAAAY too thick so i added 2 cups of warm skim milk to thin it out. Almost forgot-- also added a cup of frozen corn.   Very very yummy recipe which I will definitely be making again but next time I will 1) Use the quick cook rice 2) make less roux, since I think it was too thick (and I like thick soups)3) add more veggies, maybe green beans?  I had a little bit of left overs and it's so thick that I will make a mini pot pie with it tonight.   Definitely a winner for a cold day!

This recipe was spectacular. I prepared this as a main meal for me and my boyfriend and he was shocked because of the restaurant-like flavor. I made some modifications. I didn't have wild quick cooking rice so I used arborio rice. First, I sautee some fresh baby portobello mushrooms then added it to the boiling water and waited some minutes (like ten) for the rice to be cooked. Then followed the recipe as it is established but because I didn't have the seasoning packet I used some basil, parsley and fresh black pepper and salt to my taste.

text:
This soup is absolutely delicious!  I had never made soup before (dry mixes don't count!) so I was a bit nervous about how it would turn out, but I needn't have worried, it was great!  I took Carrie's cues and added onion, garlic, celery and carrots to give it a little more body, then cut the butter and flour and used skim milk instead of heavy cream.  For those of you who are counting calories, this cut the recipe to about 230 cal/cup instead of over 300.  Even my husband, who is "anti-soup" loved it and took some of the leftovers for lunch today!  This is definitely going in my recipe box.  Thanks!

text:
I just made this soup and had a tiny bowl before dinner to "test" it. It is SO good. I made this especially for my Cream of Chicken and Rice soup-loving husband. I can't believe how good it is! I took one reviewer's tip and just boiled my two chicken breasts in 6 cups of water and used that as my broth/water. I also took the suggestion of adding carrot, celery and onion that I finely chopped in my food processor. I went with the full amount of butter the recipe calls for as well as used heavy cream (I had some leftover from Thanksgiving that I wanted to use up) I decreased the amount of flour to 1/2 cup and also used instant white rice instead of wild (personal preference). It's snowing here today and this is going to be the perfect thing to come home to tonight when we get back in from sledding! Thanks for posting!!

Wow!  Just made this and love it!  I followed others suggestions by adding carrot and onion.  I first minced the raw chicken breasts and browned them in olive oil, then tossed in 3 shredded carrots and 1/2 minced onion and cooked addtional 2-3 minutes.  Then I added the broth and water and stirred in a box of Uncle Ben's original long grain and wild rice (because I didn't have the quick cook).  Covered the stock pot and let cook for 25 minutes.  Meanwhile I made the roux just as the recipe stated except added 1/2 cup 1% milk in addition to the cream.  Wonderful...YUM!

text:
A 4-star recipe that becomes 5-star when you follow some of the suggestions by previous posters: reduce the butter to 6 T., the flour to 6 T., change heavy cream to combination of 1/2 and 1/2 and milk, add a little cooking sherry or white wine to the roux, omit additional salt and pepper (i found the rice seasoning packet more than adequate) ... saute celery, carrots, etc. as desired. All-in-all, a real winter standard in our house!

text:
I have never made a soup before and wanted to make chicken and wild rice for two large gatherings I had on the same weekend.  So based on all of the wonderful reviews, I decided to use this recipe and definately was not disappointed.  I followed the suggestions of other reviewers such as adding carrots, celery and onion as well as cutting down the amount of flour and butter and I used half and half and 1% milk instead of cream.  In addition, I also did the unthinkable and made 40 servings-worth instead of the 8 the recipe is made for.  While that added extra time to preparation and cooking, I am thrilled to say the soup turned out simply amazing and that everyone who had it loved it and wanted the leftovers and recipe (even those who self-admittedly don't like soup that much).  Thanks for posting this recipe, it's delicious!

text:
Yummmy! I will be making this a fall/winter staple for sure!  I made some changes.  I chopped up one large carrot, one celery stalk, one onion, and one clove of garlic and sauteed w 2 tablespoons olive oil til tender.  I then added 2 diced up RAW chiken breasts and sauteed another 5 minutes.  I added the water and a half a cup of raw white rice and simmered for 30 mintues.  I added one bullion cube and only used about half the roux. The rice might have added alot of thickness cause even with just half the roux....it was thick and creamy!!! Next time I will add more carrots and celery and use 1% milk instead of the cream.  Thanks!

text:
I altered the instructions a bit for a one-pot soup.  I chopped and sauted the chicken with 1/2 of a chopped onion in 1 tbsp. EVOO and set it aside.  Then made the roux using 1/4 cup butter and 1/4 cup flour, then adding 1 cup milk and 1 cup 1/2 & 1/2.  Then added the seasoning, then 6 cups chicken stock in stead of the 4 cups stock and 2 cups water.  When everything was a smooth consistencey, I added the chicken and simmered 20 minutes, b/c that's what the wild rice box stated and my rice was not cooked after the 15 min.  Very good and next time will add a 1/4 cup white wine.

text:
This was really good soup.  I added a second box of Rice a Roni and instead of water used more chicken broth (a total of eight cups of broth if using two boxes, otherwise six cups).  
I added carrots, celery and onion with the butter and sweated them for a few minutes.  I used skim milk which thickened very well with the flour mixture.  I let the soup simmer for an hour or so to let everything marry and then dug into the greatest chicken and wild rice soup I've ever made.

This soup was amazing!! Nice and hearty and perfect for a cold Winter day. I prefer more rice, so I would recommend using two boxes of rice (one seasoning packet) but I did not know that ahead of time so I used some white rice that I had on hand it was good that way too. Hubby loved it. I took it to work to share with my co-workers the next day and rave reviews there as well. Altough, soup gets REALLY thick the next day so prepare to doctor it up before you serve.

This soup is the best I've had.  Like in the restaurants!  Very easy to make also.  I did change a few things.  I added 4 bouillon cubes and 6 cups of water and boiled the chicken in that. Then added the chicken back in.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great soup!  I did make a few changes.  I browned 1 large chicken breast half in a small amount of oil, then seasoned with sea salt and freshly ground pepper.  I added 1/2c chicken broth to skillet with chicken, covered pan and simmered chicken till done.  Meanwhile, I sauteed some onion, celery and carrot (all finely chopped) in 2-3T butter till almost soft and then added 1/2c chicken broth from chicken breast and simmered till real soft.  I also decreased flour (too thick) and used half and half instead of cream (milk would be fine too).

text:
I have tried a few of the chicken and rice soup recipes on this site and this is by far the best as is.  It is also a very flexible recipe as well.  Want to add in celery and carrots?  Go ahead!  Don't have heavy cream?  Use milk!  It will still come out great.  Don't have the quick cooking rice and seasoning packet?  Use the rice you have, if needed cook a bit longer, and add in tons of poultry seasoning and whatever other seasoning you want.  It probably won't be as good as the original recipe (at least it wasn't for me) but it is still very good.

text:
I have made this recipe 3 times now and we love it! I use a box of traditional Uncle Ben's wild rice that simmers for 25 min and to the rice and broth mixture I add onion, celery and carrots to make it a more hearty soup. Then I use leftover chicken or I boil chicken separately and add it to the soup when I add the roux. I use regular 1 or 2% milk...the cream is too rich for us. Fast, easy and fool-proof. Will make over and over again. Thanks for a great recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this soup using some of the  additional ingredients suggested by others:  diced carrots, celery and one shallot I had on hand (I didn't have any onions).  I also left out the additional 1/2 tsp of salt in the roux and substituted 1 cup of 1% milk for 1 cup of the heavy cream.   I used a regular (not quick-cooking) white and wild rice mix (8 oz. size) that had the seasoning in the mix, not in a separate packet.  I increased the water to 3 cups to be sure there would be enough liquid.  Next time I think I may use all chicken broth for the liquid.  My husband thought it was delicious.  I thought it was a little bland.  We had enough left over to freeze for another  meal.  All in all, I would definitely make this again.  I think I just need to tweak it a little more for my taste.

text:
I made this in the crock pot, per one reviewer's advice. Turned out wonderful. However, we are big soup eaters, so this only made four large bowls of soup for us. I did saute onion/carrot/celery first, although the veggies were plenty soft when eaten, so probably not necessary; next time will just add them raw. Used half/half rather than cream or milk. Just what I had that needed to be used. I think milk will work just as well. Used cornstarch rather than flour to thicken, as my hubby is on keto. Also per another reviewer, threw in a bay leaf, 1 tsp of sage, and 1/2 tsp of minced garlic.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is SUPER GOOD, just needs a few moderations to make it even better. 1) I boiled 2 large chicken breasts. I didn't want to throw away the water from this and thought it would give the soup a bit more flavor than plain water called for, so I used it up in the soup  2) I sauteed onion and carrots for a bit more flavor and added to soup. 3) I used 1/4 cup butter and 1/4 olive oil to make the roux and to make it a bit healthier 4) I used 1/2 cup half and half milk and 1 1/2 cups 1% milk to cut back on fat. 5) the biggest change that added tons more flavor was using white pepper instead of black and adding about 1/4 teaspoon or so of celery seeds. Served with crispy french bread. Delicious!

It was  great!   Here are the adjustments I made:
 2 T diced onions
3 T diced celery
12 small carrots diced
sauteed veggies in 2 T of butter  then added broth, water and chicken and seasonings to soup
4 cups broth
3 cups of water
6 oz wild rice - Uncle Bens
used about 2 T of Arrowroot powder instead of flour
used 1 cup of 2% milk instead of heavy cream

This is my favorite soup recipe.  I too sauté carrot, celery, and onion before adding the broth/chicken.  3/4 flour is too much and make the soup too thick. Try 1/2 C.  I use gf flour because my son has celiac, so maybe that is the problem? Either way you don't have to use all of the flour because it will also thicken even more the next day.

Made as directed, it’s very thick -  mounds up  in the bowl. Sort of a cross between a casserole and soup. To make it more soup like, use 4 tablespoons flour, 4 tablespoons butter for the two cups of half and half. We quite liked it thick and I will definitely make it again.

text:
I had such high hopes for this recipe, but sadly, I was overwhelmed by the butter. I may try this again using less. It was rich beyond the butter, but by how much, I cannot tell. If I try this soup again, I may use half & half instead of the heavy cream. As best I can tell, the flavor was alright - just far too buttery for our tastes. I might also add some finely diced carrot next time; a little veggies might be good, and it'll certainly add to the color. I do think this is probably a good soup, other than our 'butter problem'. Actually, I probably *will* try this soup again. Thanks, Stephanie G!!

country:
None
text:
This has been become a family favorite - getting three picky kids to agree is feat! I’ve made it plenty of times as is and it’s yummy. Over the years, I’ve modified a few things. I never have cooked chicken ready, so I’ve started poaching the chicken with chopped carrots, celery and onions for 10-15 min. Then shred and dump back in the “broth” (which is more than the 2 cups water listed, usually about four). This adds a bit more depth to the soup. I then add bone broth and follow directions as listed. Milk or half & half is fine if you don’t have/want cream.

text:
Our Publix chain of grocery stores sells in their deli a chicken and wild rice soup that I love.  I was looking for something that I could make myself thus not having to buy theirs.  Well I found it!!  This is even better!!  Here are the changes I made.  I cut the recipe in half since during summer months I usually don't eat as much soup.  I used "Uncle Bens Long grain rice quick cook".  I cooked about 1/4 cup each of chopped fine onion, celery and carrots with the melting butter and spices from Uncle Ben.  I used lowfat milk instead of heavy cream.  I used 1/2 the breast leftovers from a rotisserie chicken.  I boiled those bones to make my own broth.  So very good!!!

userID:
24844017
Display Name:
TamTam
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like everything I cook, I doctored this recipe up a bit.  I simmered the chicken in water until it literally fell apart.  On the side, I saute'd the onion, celery, garlic, carrots, and broccoli bits with some herbs and spices, in olive oil.  When everything was opaque I simply added it to the soup.  I used 1/2 rice.  When the chicken and water boiled down until it was reduced by half, that's when I added the wild rice.  On the side I mixed 1/4 cup of flour and 1/2 c milk.  When rice is almost done, I poured 1 cup of 2% milk into the broth mix.  I added 2 T butter.  I cooked for roughly another 10 - 15 minutes before adding the flour/milk.  I used a little at a time until the soup was where I wanted it to be. This delicious soup was served with garlic sticks.  Yummy!!  Thanks for sharing your recipe??

Very good recipe, I used Farmhouse chicken and wild rice which is very good tasting. I took other suggestions and added carrots, celery and onions chopped up and added that to the butter. I sautéed that for five minutes then added the flour and seasoning packet. Cook that for another five minutes and then added 1/2 cream and 1/2 milk, which then added that to the rice in the broth that has been cooking 15 minutes before hand with 1/2 teaspoon of thyme., cooked another 15 minutes adding in rotisserie chicken.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave the recipe 3 starts because for my taste buds it was bland in flavor, too thick and too fatty but was a good base soup. I did like most people on here add fried onion/carrots/mushrooms/garlic, also added peas, added my own spices and herbs that I like ( turmeric, smoked paprika, saffron, dry basil and fresh dill). I used white jasmine rice, as I love this rice, plus when its cooked, it has rich/smooth, slightly sticky texture. To make it less sticky rinse rice few times in cold water.  I also used store bought rotisserie chicken, that gave soup more nice flavor.  I didnt have time to make roux, so I used some canned cream of chicken and Alfredo sauce. I dont like very thick soups.

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I’ve made this soup many times over the years and only make a couple of modifications. My family loves having it a bit more chunky so, I sauté diced carrots and celery in about a tablespoon of butter for a few minutes just to soften them a bit. I also can never find quick cooking long grain and wild rice in my area so I use regular Rice a Roni, add it to the celery and carrots, add the broth and water, bring to a boil, cover and let simmer for about 25 min. I’ll then add the roux mix and chicken once it’s done simmering. I also use rotisserie chicken from the store, shred it and add as much as I like. The rice is always cooked nicely and my family loves it!!

text:
Have made this many times - tonight I used vegan Ripple half and half, better than boullion no chicken base, gluten free flour, soy free earth Balance, sautéed onion, celery, and carrots. Out of garlic. Skipped the chicken. I let it cook down a bit as it seemed a little thin at first but it did get quite thick. 

So so good. If I hadn’t made it myself I would have never guessed it was vegan. It was my first time using Ripple plant milk - usually I use canned coconut milk for creamy soups but my son doesn’t care for it and I wasn’t sure how it would work here. Next time I’ll add more vegerables and maybe some mushrooms.

userID:
16954885
Display Name:
Chris
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
7
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this a few times and I have some mods that enhance it. Cook chicken stock or broth with rice/seasoning mix. In separate pan add carrots, celery, onion, and garlic to oil & butter until mix starts to soften. Add flour to vegetables to then milk/cream to create roux. Add roux/veg mix to rice/stock mix then add cooked chicken to pot. Saute mushrooms in butter then add to pot. I add chicken "better than boullion" paste to give deeper chicken flavor.  Also try adding a little curry to the mix, it makes chicken taste more "chicken-y".  If I want thicker soup I make more butter/flour/milk roux to add. Want creamier soup? Add more cream/milk. Want thinner soup? Add more chicken broth. Probably need to add more broth on day 2 after the rice absorbs more of the liquid overnight.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-11-26T01:08:44.947
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
4636698
Display Name:
TransplantedHusker
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed this before as it's been my go to recipe for years!!! I urge everyone to make this recipe just as written as it is DIVINE!!! This recipe as never once failed.  I always make this after Thanksgiving to use up any leftover turkey and gravy, and any leftover bits of veggies such as celery and onion. I boil down the turkey bones to make the best stock ever and use this for the base with water. I throw in any leftover veggies with the stock and rice. I use leftover gravy as part of the butter /flour roux. Word of caution, if you start adding leftovers and such, be careful with the seasonings as your soup may have plenty of salt and pepper and does't need any additional seasoning. Also I, too, have made this with milk, part milk /part evaporated milk, etc. This recipe is so very forgiving. ENJOY!

text:
Absolutely perfect for anyone who wants to have something filling and satisfying on a chilly, rainy day in Autumn ??. I didn't have any cream, so I used evaporated milk and regular 2% milk with a little extra butter instead. 

What I love most about this meal is that the ingredients are usually in my pantry, no need to go out and grab anything while the weather is yucky! I'm absolutely making this soup to bring to a gathering I'm attending this weekend too!

Oh...also, I doubled the recipe to bring a home cooked meal to both of my kids (ages 20 and 23) who live on their own now. They are always trying to make ends meet, so I doubt either has had a decent meal in ages! Also, there's my own (not so distant) memories of when my husband and I were their age, living on our own... My husband and I both worked full time, however, all we usually had in our refrigerator was a bottle of ketchup and some leftover Chinese takeout, lol! We'll never forget the week when all we had to eat was Top Ramen and we were absolutely broke! Talk about creative dinners! I should have written a cookbook called, "101 different recipes using Ramen." ??

This beautiful soup is so simple and delightfully satisfying that I wish I'd found it sooner! Thank you!

After reading reviews, I added 1/2 c. each of diced onion, carrot and celery, plus 2 cloves of garlic. I roasted the chicken breasts, substituted olive oil for the butter (1 T. to sauté vegetables, and 4 T. with 1/2 c. flour to make the roux. I cooked rice separately in 2 c. water. When I mixed everything together, I added about 1/4 tsp. ground white pepper, in addition to the salt and pepper, along with 1/4 c. sauvignon blanc. Will definitely be adding this in our fall/winter rotation.

userID:
3829322
Display Name:
Wendibird4
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
52
favoritesCount:
661
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's good, but in my opinion needs some work to be great. 

I added celery, onion, and carrot because I can't imagine this type of soup without a mirepoix. I didn't want to add the rice seasoning packet because I don't care for the artificial, chemical flavors in seasoned rice mixes (just my personal preference), but unfortunately I was unable to find a white/wild blend that had a separate seasoning packet so I gave it a go. I used Zataran's brand with onion and garlic spice mix. The flavor overwhelmed the rich, gentler flavors that I love in this type of soup. To be fair, I didn't use the correct type of rice, however, the recipe didn't specify a brand or type to use and I looked all over for a brand that had a separate seasoning packet. I feel the recipe could have been more clear in this regard. 

Mixing the cream into the roux was a bit of a pain because it resulted in a thick batter consistency which I'm sure would have caused lumps had I added it directly to the pot with the chicken broth as instructed. Instead, I added a few ladle fulls of broth to the cream mixture to thin it out more before adding it to the broth. This resulted in a silky smooth soup. Not a big deal, but could be difficult for a novice cook. 

There wasn't as much rice in the soup as I would have liked. Next time I'll buy a plain white and wild mix (if I can find one) and cook it separately so I can add as much rice as I like.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-08-31T00:10:12.143
helpfulCount:
0

text:
Excellent and easy! As many other reviewers I started by sautéing some onion, carrots and celery with a tablespoon of butter until they started to soften. Then I added cut up meat from a rotisserie chicken, broth, water and 2 (14 oz) cans of cooked wild rice. I made the roux as stated adding some garlic to the melted butter and some oregano and rosemary into the flour. I know some reviewers get upset by all the substitutions, but for me veggies in this soup are a must have!

text:
I have made this at least a dozen times adding different vegetables that I had available. The recipe is 5 stars just the way it is. I had to stop making it because of my husband’s dietary needs. I decided to try it again with some adjustments. I used 1/4 cup plus 2 TB spoons of olive oil in place of the butter and used half and half instead of cream. The roux came out just fine and it still had a ton of flavor. I’m glad I came back to this recipe to try it again.

userID:
20690488
Display Name:
sak5
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So I did made quite a few changes but we LOVED how it turned out... a bit spicier with more of a broth since both me and my guy were sick. I omitted the cream/milk and the flour. Only used 1 tbsp with some olive oil to sauté a chopped onion, 3 cloves garlic, 2 celery stalks and two carrots first. Boiled the chicken breasts in 6 cups broth (added maybe 1.5 cups water) then shredded. Made wild rice in a separate pan and set aside. Added sautéed veggies to the broth from the chicken as well as a one head of chopped bok choy stems (set aside leaves and added the last 15 min of cooking) a diced red pepper, some tobasco peppers (just took some from a jar of trappys Hot vinegar) some chopped scapes, a chopped zucchini.. and any other veggies I could find. Added the rice back in and let all simmer. Then I added about 3/4 teaspoon basil and oregano, a pinch of thyme, couple shakes of cayenne pepper, some spicy garlic salt and a few shakes of red pepper flakes as well as the recipes salt and pepper. From there it was filled with delicious flavors.. May have added a touch more cayenne just for taste. We couldn’t stop eating it. A must if you want a little kick to your chicken/veggie/rice soup!

country:
None
text:
Made this almost exactly as directed. My only changes were adding a little extra salt and pepper, as well as a dash of garlic powder, and substituting whole milk for the heavy dream. It still came out rich, creamy and delicious.  Unlike many soups, this was an entirely filling meal all on its own. In fact, the texture was so thick that I think you could cut back to 1/2 cup of flour, if desired. Next time I may sauté some vegetables as other reviewers have suggested--the soup needs nothing else to be delicious and substantial, but the flavor could easily carry some veggies too. This recipe will be going into the regular rotation!

This soup was hearty and comforting ! As many reviewers did, I started by sautéing  some onions, garlic, celery and carrots. I added the broth and water. I let the veggies simmer till soft then added the chicken and rice. At the same time, I was making the roux on anoter burner. For that I cut the butter down to 5 Tablespoons and the flour to 1/3 cup and used 2% milk for the cream. the soupe was plenty creamy and delicious despite the modifications made.

text:
This soup is delicious! I did make a few changes. I sauteed 1/2 to 3/4 cup each of chopped carrots and celery with 1 whole (but small) chopped onion (about 1 cup), and two garlic cloves. After that I proceeded with the usual recipe (using rotisserie chicken instead of breasts... I was being lazy, but it worked perfectly) , but used 2% milk in place of the cream. Next time I will have to figure out how to make it without using a whole stick of butter. Yikes! It was incredibly tasty, though, and easily rivals or outshines anything you would find in a restaurant.

text:
Poached two chicken breasts, sautéed onion/carrots/celery as another reviewer suggested, used chicken stock vs broth. Subbed half skim milk. Was very creamy, very filling. I thought the flavor was a little lacking, so added thyme, salt, some white wine. Still wasn't quite there (maybe a dollop of Better than Bouillon would have deepened the flavor as desired). Took about 2 hours for me to make due to the poaching, veg sauté, and my pokiness when making a recipe for the first time. :-) Definitely thickened up; suggest having an addl cup or two of broth in reserve in case it's needed or for reheating. My family didn't love it, so I'm not sure I'll make this again.

text:
WOW!!WOW!!WOW!!  Can I give it 10 stars?  This will be part of my regular soup rotation from now on!  I know it annoys some to change the recipe then rate it; but after reading multiple reviews, I felt a few changes would improve a great base recipe.  I added salt and pepper to the chicken and cooked it in my Copper XL pot  to avoid using oil.  I followed some other reviewers suggestions and sauteed 1/2 cup each diced carrots, onion, and celery, mixed with 2 tsp minced garlic in the juice from the cooked chicken.  I used a 5.5oz bag of Knorr Rice Sides Chicken and Broccoli mix (since I didn't have what the recipe called for), directly to the chicken mixture rather than the roux.   I also added 2-3 dashes each of poultry seasoning,  onion powder, parsley flakes, and garlic powder and an additional 1 cup of water  to the mix so the end product wasn't too thick, but remained flavorful.  I used 1/2 cup flour and 6 Tbsp butter with 2 cups milk for the roux to reduce calories and it was plenty thick and creamy.  Very, very delicious and colorful (especially with the carrots, broccoli, and parsley)!  Thank you for this excellent recipe!

text:
This is such a go-to recipe.  I've altered this recipe every time I've made it, and every time it comes out awesome.  I use boneless chicken thighs instead of chicken breasts since they are more moist.  The last time I made it, I added a whole package of wild rice, along with the wild rice mix, since wild rice doesn't absorb liquids like rice does and adds so much more to the soup.   

This is definitely a jump-off recipe for making all kinds of variations of this amazing soup.

text:
With a few small tweaks, this is a VERY delicious soup! For the rice, I used slightly more (6.2 oz box of Uncle Ben’s Fast Cook, Long Grain and Wild Rice).  Therefore, I used about 3 TBS less flour.  For the chicken, I bought a rotisserie chicken from Walmart. I put all of the meat in. (It was about 3 and 1/2 cups shredded.) Also, I added a few shakes of dried onion flakes and about a fourth teaspoon minced garlic (from a jar). Other than these changes, I followed out the rest of the recipe as originally written. When done, I topped with chunks of ripe, chilled tomato. Yum! When you’re heat it the next day, just stir in some water to get it back to the consistency of your liking. This recipe is a keeper.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made it with these changes:  used real wild rice (not instant), added about 3/4 cup diced carrots, 1/2 cup diced celery, 3 medium-sized garlic cloves & 5 medium Crimini mushrooms sliced, to the veggie mixture and sautéed lightly.  Used Half & Half instead of heavy cream. Since there was no seasoning pack in my real wild rice, I just seasoned with pink sea salt, fresh ground pepper, some Lawry's seasoning salt and a couple shakes of Penzey's Tuscan seasoning mix.  Next time I will double the amount of wild rice...4 ounces is just not enough for my taste.  Will try adding 1/2 cup good dry white wine to liquid (reducing water by same amount) or maybe a few tablespoons of sherry before serving.  It needs a little more oomph in the flavor area.

text:
Wow! This was amazing and incredibly easy. I made it on a rainy day and everyone loved it (well, except for one extremely picky son who said it made him gag, but he's another story). Following other reviewers' suggestions, I added 1 cup carrots, half a cup of celery, and sautéed it with butter and onion. It needed to go in the fridge for a few hours before I served it, and it got really thick, almost solid. I added more chicken broth, reheated it, and it turned out fine. If you're going to add vegetables I suggest increasing the liquid accordingly.

text:
I made this soup for one of my church's Lenten suppers.  I sautéed in about 2 tablespoons of olive oil:  1/2 cup chopped onion, 1/2 cup chopped celery, 1/2 cup chopped carrot, and one minced clove of garlic, and added this to the soup.  Also, I used only 1/2 cup flour and 6 tablespoons of butter for the roux.  I substituted 1 cup half and half, and 1 cup 2% milk for the 2 cups of heavy cream.  The soup was very creamy.  There were no leftovers that evening.  I received several compliments, and two people asked me for the recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Couldn't decide between 4 or 5 stars. Went with 5 because I didn't follow the recipe exactly and it may have been better had I. I found it a little bland. That may have been my fault because I forgot to add the salt in the flour mixture and I used low sodium chicken broth. Here's how I made this. I boiled my chicken in salted and herbed water until almost fully cooked. Then I cubed it. Sautéed onions, carrots, celery, garlic and peas till done. Then added the chicken cubes to finish cooling them. Then I pretty much followed the rest of the recipe except I used 6Tbs butter with 1/2 cup flour and I used about 1 cup half and half and 1 cup 1% milk instead of the cream. My husband loved this but my kids (ages 15 &18) didn't. But they aren't soup lovers. I don't think I'll make this again as it wasn't super quick and only my husband was a big fan.

I made this soup exactly as written so that I could rate it fairly.  It was super yummy!! I would recommend it to anyone.  I have a wild rice casserole recipe that includes all of the same ingredients only adds mushrooms and pimentos. text:
I was a little skeptical about using a boxed rice mix for this soup, but I was pleased with the end result. I did add a half-onion, several celery stalks & three carrots cut in 1/2 inch pieces and a couple garlic cloves coarsely chopped, which I sautéed for a few minutes in olive oil prior to adding the chicken and broth. I cut the flour & butter to 3 tbsp each and used primarily milk with about a 1/4 cup of heavy cream. I added more broth as I like a thinner soup. I will make this again. This is a great way to use leftover roast chicken.

text:
This was an easy quick win of a recipe.  My daughter loved it and I have made it twice now.  Only change I made was to increase the amount of the chicken broth as the rice was absorbing the liquid after a day and it was more wild rice casserole vs a soup.

userID:
4129504
Display Name:
Heather
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7802360.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent!!!  Put 1 carton (4c) Swanson vegetable broth, 2 c water, roasted turkey breast in pot. Bring to boil. Add Rice A Roni Long Grain and Wild Rice Original (box) rice only. Remove from heat. Sauté 3-4 large carrots, 3-4 stalks celery and 1/2 chopped onion in 2T butter. When soft, add 4T butter to melt. Add 1/4 - 1/2 cup flour. *consider reducing to 1/4c. Brown a bit/make roux.  Add 1 cup skim milk (Fairlife).  Bring pot with broth back to simmer. Add in creamy roux. Add in rice seasoning packet. *Soup gets VERY thick when cooking/cooling.  Seasoned with salt, pepper and celery salt.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a good base, and you can make it heartier by changing some things up.  
I used 2 rotisserie chicken (save time) 
I used 7 cups of chicken stock. 
2 cans of cream of chicken soup with 2 cans of water.  
Added 2 more cups of water. 

Sautéed onions and minced garlic.  Added it to the broth. Added chicken.  
Added chopped carrots and celery.
Added 5 boxes of long grain and wild rice, with their seasoning packets to the soup.  

In a pan I used 1/2 cup of butter, melt it, then added 3/4 cup of flour. 
I then added 2 cups of heavy cream, and about a tbls of pepper. Stirred until thick.  Added flour mixture to my soup, and stirred.

Let simmer, until veggies are nice and tender and rice is done.  
Served with fresh baked bread.  

**note, my method makes a huge batch of soup.  
Perfect for freezing....add milk or water when reheating to thin the soup out to your liking. **

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just got done making this for dinner tonight. I made a few changes, well better yet additions. I used bone-in chicken and added it to the broth and water. To this I also added approximately 1/2 cup of each celery, carrots, and onions chopped.  Also two cloves of garlic minced. Then I brought it to a boil and turned it down to simmer for approximately 30 minutes. I then removed the chicken and sat it aside to cool, so I could pick the meat off the bones while I was making the roux. Add the chicken back in right before I added the cream mixture. Turned out wonderful!

text:
This soup is wonderful and full of flavor. I had to make some adjustments as it was a little too creamy for my taste. The flour was too much, so I reduced it 1/4-1/2c stirring it in slowly. Omit the salt, sauté some  onions, celery and carrots before adding the liquids. I also use rice milk and earth balance butter as we are dairy free. Still turns out great!

text:
I make this to take to ski lodges in a food thermos, and to cozy up with in a mug on movie nights.  The one change I suggest making is to use 2 percent milk instead of the cream. Yesss we know cream is delicious, yesss it makes this recipe insanely good, but your heart, yo.  It's already a pretty inflammatory recipe.  Also- I usually get the regular long-cooking rice version of the Uncle Ben's mix and just cook it beforehand according to the box directions then dump it in. Fan.tas.tic.

country:
None
text:
It's 16 degrees today so I decided this would be a good hot comfort dish and I was right! Absolutely delicious and pretty easy to make.  Of course, I did make a few adjustments.  I only used 6 T butter and that was plenty. I also cut up carrots and celery and added to the chicken/broth mixture. I boiled that mixture a little longer to soften the veggies and added 1 extra cup of broth.  I also used 1-1/2 c of 2% milk and 1/2 c half and half as I thought heavy cream would be too heavy. I used a rotessiere chicken.  It makes a lot so I'm hoping I can freeze some. It's a keeper.

region:

country:
None
text:
I make this hearty soup year round and it's always a hit with my husband! Like any home cook, I've added and subtracted as I saw fit and did what works for my family. For starters, I added veggies--celery, onion, garlic, and carrots. The extra touch adds a lot of flavor! Oftentimes, I make this as a spur of the moment dinner because it's so quick and easy. This leads me not always having fresh chicken breasts thawed and ready. In the event this happens, I add frozen diced chicken breasts (we buy it for salads) and throw it in before adding the roux. It works perfectly and makes a quick dinner even quicker.

Display Name:
MINNOW51

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has become one of my husband's favorite soups. The original recipe would get three and a half stars, but my tweaks make it a five for us. The modifications I've made  for our tastes are:  only 2-4 Tbsp butter, melted, that I saute carrots and celery in;  I use all broth (no water), some of which is  stock I make from the bones, etc. of the rotisserie chicken; two bags of Carolina (Mahatma) long grain and wild rice with the seasonings all mixed in;  1/4 cut flour and 1 cup half-and-half. No salt or pepper into the pot, but anyone is free to add it when they scoop their bowl. Sometimes I'll saute mushrooms (white or cremini) after the carrots and celery have softened.

text:
Great recipe, but we all thought is was really short on the rice. I'll double if not triple the rice next time. Also added 1 cup frozen carrot coins which I would highly recommend doing. For shredded chicken, I always just throw it in the crockpot in the morning with some chicken broth. It makes this any easy week night meal. With these small tweaks, this recipe is definitely a keeper.

text:
I love chicken and wild rice soup. I have been searching for a good recipe for a long time and finally landed on this one...only to be disappointed. I followed it exactly and it turned out way too thick and way too flour-y. I added onions and carrots to the butter and seasoning mix because it adds more flavor. But after adding in the 3/4 cup of flour I had to put in more butter, which is probably because of the veggies. By the time I followed the recipe and it was done, I took a taste test. Holy flour and cream batman! I added another cup of stock and white wine and more salt and pepper. Still didn't taste right :( The search for the perfect wild rice soup is still on.

I took the advice of so many others and sautéed about a cup each of celery and carrots. I always use a rotisserie chicken for this recipe and used 1 cup cream and 1 cup 2% milk. Everyone loves it and as a result it never lasts long!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/36706.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not really a review, but my record for myself for what  I did so I know how to get a great pot of soup again! Kids loved it.  Cooked 1 c of long grain wild rice (not a seasoned packet) according to directions and set aside. I chopped 1/2 an onion and sauteed it with 3 stalks chopped celery in olive oil and butter. Added 2 tsp garlic to that. Had 3 long chopped carrots (about 18 baby) cooking in 4 c of chicken broth till tender. Added about 1 1/2-2 c of chopped cooked chicken that I had on hand to the broth, then added celery and onion. Made a roux by melting 1/2 c butter in skillet, stirring in seasonings: poultry seasoning, white pepper, herb chicken seasoning and chopped fresh parsley, along with about 2/3 c of flour. Then added about 2/3 c of heavy cream to that. Stir rice and roux into soup mixture. Was a hit!

If I was the only person in my household rating this recipe, I would also likely give it more like 4.5 to 5 stars. But The Hubbs just doesn't get that excited about any soup. As a "food group," soup is more like a beverage to him. So, when I say that he gave this one between 3-4 stars, it really means something. I made it almost "as-written." I "took some help" from a little more than half of a rotisserie chicken and I added about a 1/2 cup (maybe a little more) of peas and carrots for color. I REALLY enjoyed this one. Next time, the biggest change I would probably make is making the roux in a larger pan -- I just didn't give myself enough room. But there certainly WILL be a next time. Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
YUM!   I had to adapt for gluten/dairy free diet restrictions but still amazing!  My picky kid loves it.    
I followed several of the reviews that suggested sauteeing onion, garlic and adding celery and carrot to the broth mixture.
I used earth balance dairy free butter,   and cashew milk to sub the dairy,   gluten free all purpose flour (similar to better batter) for the flour. Thickened up very nicely!
I couldn't find the wild rice w seasoning so I had to wing the seasonings- I used onion powder, garlic powder, salt, pepper,  cumin, ginger.  SO maybe it isn't a review of this recipe anymore,  but at least an excellent adaption for the gluten/dairy free!

text:
The recipe made as original is very good, but some additions push it into 5 star & pay for it at a restaurant.  here's my changes.  I fried up 6 pieces of bacon, then sautéed 1/2 an onion, same amount of celery & carrots & 8 oz of sliced mushrooms plus garlic in the bacon grease.  My family felt that the one box of Rice a Roni wasn't enough, so I added a 2nd.  The white sauce made w/ the flour, Half & half needed a bit more seasoning, so I added a grating of nutmeg, a handful of sharp shredded cheddar and my secret ingredient, 2 shakes of ancho chile powder, which doesn't add any heat but adds a depth of flavor that you can't explain. Oh & don't forget to dice the bacon & add it in!  YUMMY!

None
text:
Oh this soup is fantastic! I took reviewer Carrie's advice; sautéed onion, garlic, carrot & celery before adding chicken broth. I reduced flour to 1/2 cup & reduced butter to 6 T. I didn't have wild rice on hand so I used 1&1/3 cup minute rice & found a recipe for my own seasoning blend. I didn't have cream so I used whole milk.
If you're hesitant about this recipe, just do it. I haven't had creamy chicken & rice soup this good since childhood. This stuff will warm your bones on a cold night & make your tummy very happy! This is now one of my go to soups. Thanks so much for sharing your delicious recipe!

It was a cold, damp night. This warms you from the inside out!  I cut up some sharp cheddar cheese chunks to nibble on along with the soup.

text:
We really enjoyed this soup BUT I did add sauteed carrots, celery, onions and mushrooms. We like veggies in our soup. I also subbed one of the cups of heavy cream for skim milk to cut some fat and calories. I reduced the flour to a half cup but I should have used the recommended amount of flour because I would have liked this soup to be a bit thicker. Regardless, this soup served with some fresh warm bread is a meal that can't be beat. I'll definitely be making it again.

text:
I am only giving 4 stars due to modifications made...but what an awesome base recipe!!  I am certain it would be great "as is", but I kind of combined this with another recipe found on site and then followed some suggestions made by others.  I used 3 chicken breasts(boiled in homemade veggie broth), homemade chicken broth, Minnesota wild rice (cooked in chicken broth/water), sautéed celery, carrots and shallots in olive oil...added fresh mushrooms. I also used whole milk as opposed to the heavy cream and added about 3/4 cup of white wine the last 15 minutes. It was super tasty!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading several reviews, I decided to make the following modifications.  First, sautee about 1 c. onion (minced) with 4 garlic cloves (minced) in some olive oil.  Then add a 14.5 oz can sliced carrots (drained & cut into smaller pieces) and sautee it for a couple more minutes before adding it to the broth, water and chicken. I also use low sodium chicken broth, 8.5 oz of wild rice, 1/3 cup whole wheat flour, 5 tbsp. butter, and 2 cups 1% milk.   I also get a small cooked whole chicken from the grocery store and use the chicken from that.  I added 1/4 tsp Lawry's seasoned salt (in addition to the 1/2 tsp salt and 1/2 tsp pepper that the recipe calls for).  The result is a thick and creamy soup that is A-MAZING!!!

Display Name:
Meagan

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really great! I have to give it 4 stars because I altered it considerably. I only had regular wild rice, no prepackaged quick cooking. So, I cooked that ahead of time. I sauteed onions, carrots and celery in the butter. After sauteeing them until starting to get tender, I sprinkled the flour in and stirred for a minute. Then I added the chicken broth, water and 1% milk. Since I didn't have a prepackaged rice, in addition to salt and pepper, I added paprika, garlic salt (next time I'd just saute garlic with the veggies, I forgot), oregano, sage and a little turmeric for the yellow coloring. I stirred that and brought it to a boil. I stirred in the chicken, lowered the heat and let simmer for 15 minutes. I stirred in wild rice and served. It was a huge hit! My aunt in Wisconsin made us chicken and wild rice soup from a package, this was a great base that allowed us to enjoy the flavor without all the extra sodium. Thanks for sharing!

text:
Delicious! And it should be with the amount of butter and cream that is in this. But it is very filling so you don't eat a lot. I made according to directions. The only criticism I would have for this recipe is that the "10-15 min until heated through" turned out to be "until rice is burned on the bottom. Make sure you stir ever couple min or turn the heat down.  Came out to 6 very heavy bowls.

text:
Modifications:
1 cup carrots
1/2 cup celery
1 onion
1 clove garlic
5 slices bacon 

I sautéed the veggies in the bacon fat until tender then added them right before the roux. Right before serving I added the bacon and fresh thyme. It was amazing!

text:
This is the first time I tried to make a creamy recipe so I kept to the original (cream part) with lots of butter and heavy cream.  I changed a few things with the hearty ingredients though: I used 1lb ground turkey; browned it with onion and garlic. I put in fresh spinach for color and during the simmer portion I added one more box of rice-a-roni wild rice (without the packet), 1 cup of celery and 1/4 cup of white wine like one reviewer did and this came out amazing.  My waistline has increased in size just after one sitting but it was so darn delicious!! Next time I will reduce the butter and use 2% milk. Thank you for this!

text:
Followed the suggestions of others, added chopped onion, garlic, carrot, and celery, and also added a chopped red pepper, since I had one.  

I used leftover rotisserie chicken, and put the bones in the 2 cups of water and let them boil together while I made the roux.  After I took the bones out, it looked a bit lower than 2 cups, so I added some wine.

YUM!  Many thanks to all, especially the original submitter!

userID:
7218484
Display Name:
still_learnin
isPro:

0

3

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best recipe.  Made it three times this chilly winter and it's a hit every time. It's a filling meal with fresh bread and a side salad!  

No major changes - just personal preference:
1) I do add diced carrots & celery - they add some color
2) I used Uncle Bens Classiques Long Grain & Wild Rice mix - it has the seasoning packet and a dried veggies packet.
3) the flour and butter for the roux can be reduced...both for calories sake & the thickness
4) I've used milk and half and half in place of the heavy cream and both still make a very thick soup without the added calories.
5) I don't add any salt and used Campbell's 30% reduced sodium broth - the seasoning packet in the rice offers plenty of salt.

I'll be sad winter is almost over (NOT) as this is really more a fall/winter meal! Would be great to take to an après ski party or winter potluck!  Oh, and it does continue to thicken up - add a little more chicken broth and it won't dilute the flavor!!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2014-03-16T09:12:09
helpfulCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe as a base for my tastes. I took 1 qt of home made chicken stock and 4 whole,skinless,chicken legs,(legs and thighs separated),put them in the crockpot on low,and let them simmer overnight. In the morning I drained the legs,reserving stock, let cool,and picked & chopped the meat. In the crockpot I threw a whole 6 oz.package of brown & wild mix,into the already hot reserved broth. In a stock pot, I sauteed in 2 TBS olive oil, 1 whole leek,tougher parts of green top removed, 1 cup each celery hearts and carrots,chopped, and 6 oz. mushrooms,diced small, until tender. I added to the stock pot 1 qt of homemade chicken broth and reserved broth/rice mixture,chicken meat, & I brought all to a boil and let simmer. I add an additional 1/2 C. wild rice mix & cook until tender. I wanted less calories so I used 6 TBS unsalted butter and 1/2 C.flour to make roux, and add 2 C. 1 percent milk. This makes 12 servings, and was a big hit at a church pot luck. (Approx. 286 calories).

text:
My husband LOVED this soup. I halved the recipe and could'nt find quick cooking long grain wild rice so I cooked uncle bens rice mix in the broth after I sauteed chopped carrots celery and onion in some butter. Added the roux and it was really thick so I thinned it out a little with some milk. I used the entire flavor packet even though I halved the recipe. I garnished with some grated sharp cheddar but I don't think it added much to the soup. Having the leftovers tomorrow and I think I'll add crumbled bacon on top instead. My husband said it's a keeper, five stars! I thought it needed more depth of flavor but it was tasty.

text:
Wonderful, warm and delicious soup.  A couple things that I did could only have improved on the original recipe.  I sauteed a big carrot, two stalks of celery, an onion and two garlic cloves in EVOO before proceeding to step two.  The next time I make this, I will be doubling up on the wild rice mix as the soup is pretty thin otherwise (creamy, but thin).  I also used a mixture of half and half and skim milk for the roux and didn't notice any negative effect.  Very nice recipe to play with.

country:
None
text:
This was awesome! I sautéed cut up chicken breasts in olive oil, added onion, carrots, celery, and garlic - then added about 6 cups water and concentrated chicken broth - added rice, let it all simmer for about 30 minutes - I didn't do the whole roux, add cream and simmer step, I just melted 1/4 cup butter and added 1/4 cup flour, stirred till smooth and added the seasoning packet from the rice - dumped it in the boiling pot, and it thickened up great! I added cream, but really only about 1/3 cup, didn't measure just dumped in what I had left in the container! Turned out great, very thick and delicious! :)

text:
I "tweaked" this recipe. I roasted a chicken early in the day and used the carcass to make my own chicken stock. I used 6 cups of my homemeade stock and omitted the 2 cups of water. I don't buy pre-seasoned rice, so I just cooked my favorite rice blend then added it to the hot chicken stock. After adding the chicken, rice and cream blend, I tasted and added 3 bay leaves, some turmeric and some Italian seasonings. Served this with some hearty dinner rolls and it was a hit!

userID:
2402378
Display Name:
Erin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
20
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
149
favoritesCount:
890
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/46210.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
GREAT with TONS OF CHANGES.  I cannot give a recipe five stars after I have pillaged it and transformed it into something almost unrecognizable from the original recipe. This soup is bland without serious help. Here's what I did to save mine: I sautéed half a sweet onion, 2.5 celery stalks, about 3 carrots and several mushrooms with 3 strips of Neman Ranch applewood smoked bacon and about 2 tablespoons of butter until tender. I transferred veggies to a paper towel to drain the grease & discarded remaining grease from the pan. I used about 1/4 cup white wine to deglaze the pan. I then added chicken stock, water and rice (after a boil). I used about 1/2 cup flour because I have no idea what kind of box of rice this author used -- I have never seen that size from Uncle Ben's or any other brand. I used a 6oz box so I decreased the flour. I used 1.5 cups heavy cream and the rest half and half. When I combined everything, I realized there was far too little rice for my liking. So I added one 90 second microwaveable Uncle Ben's long grain and wild rice pouch, cooked. I also added about three tablespoons of Better than Bouillon (chicken flavor). I needed some additional salt and pepper and two good dollops more "salted" butter before FINALLY I had a restaurant quality soup. Nevermind it could choke Paula Deen it's so fattening & full of butter. I'll work on lightening it up next time. Anyhoo -- great recipe inspiration but not a great recipe without massive overhaul.

country:
None
text:
Awesome Restaurant Quality!  Made minimal changes....DOUBLE THE RECIPIE...YOU WILL BE GLAD YOU DID!  Always start with a mirepoix(carrots,celery,onion)! Used a whold bag of finely chopped carrots and a whole bag peeled and finely chopped celery. You want the celery,carrots and onions to be a little bigger in size than the rice.  Fried those in a little oil for about 5 minutes then added 1 cup finely chopped onions to that mix and sauteed' for another 5.  Also used a rotisserie chicken that I shreded, leaving off the skin.  Also down graded the flour to 1/2 cup when making the roux'(flour and butter.  Note...you MUST add the liquid to the roux' NOT the roux' to the liquid or you will get lumps.  Also used a 6.5oz package of wild rice.  Outstanding soup! My daughter ate if for 3 days straight.  After sitting overnight, the soup became way too thick, but I just added more chicken stock and it was excellent.

text:
My family (including my two picky daughters) really loved this soup.  A friend shared the recipe and I've made it three times now.  One thing I would recommend is cutting down on the amount of flour.  I used 1/2 cup and I believe that 1/3 cup would be plenty.  The soup was almost too thick and less flour made it a little more soup-like.  I also used 1% milk instead of cream and it was just as tasty but obviously much healthier.  And for the chicken, I used a Costco rotisserie chicken.

text:
As written, I thought this recipe was just ok. The butter and heavy cream is way too much. I like a creamy soup as much as the next person, but this was way too rich. Next time we would eliminate the butter entirely and probably use half and half instead of heavy cream. We added carrots, celery, and corn because when we make soup we like it to be a complete meal. Without the added veggies I think this soup would be pretty boring. With modifications I think this can be a 5 star recipe, but not as written.

Just made this for dinner and it was delicious.  My husband loved it!  Did a few things differently after reading the other reviews.  I sautéed an onion, once celery stalk and some chopped baby carrots in butter and garlic first.  Then added the broth and water, using an extra cup of water to make up for the added veggies.  I used the whole box of rice (6 oz.).  For the roux, I used 6 tbsp. of butter and less flour (about 1/3 cup).  Definitely recommend it!

text:
5 stars with the modifications suggested by a few people! I made this as healthy as possible by sauteeing lots of carrots and onion in olive oil and garlic, using skim milk, whole wheat flour (cut down to 1/2 cup as suggested), and cut the butter way down to 6 Tbsp as suggested. I also used real wild rice, so had to cook it most of the way before starting this recipe.
If you are used to eating healthy foods, you will not notice the lack of cream by using milk- in fact, I can't imagine using cream or it would have seemed too rich to me since I'm not used to eating like that. I also can't imagine the recipe without carrots and veggies. They are essential!

text:
This is now my go-to soup recipe. Its comes together quickly, especially when I use leftover chicken. I choose 1% milk, 1/2 cup flower, 6 tablespoons of butter and do add some carrots and celery like many others. I even add some quartered small tomatoes, 5 minutes before its time to eat. They add color and don't "feel mushy". Then I like to serve it in sourdough bread bowls (or small sub rolls). Its fun to eat and gets the wow effect.

text:
Oh. My. Gosh. It's like heaven in a bowl!

I followed the recipe as closely as I could (chicken was not cooked; wild rice mix was not quick-cooking; half-and-half had to step in for heavy cream). My improvising did not detract from the deliciousness of this soup in any way. I look forward to making this again and again!

(I served it with garlic and cheese-style biscuits, like you-know-where serves. They were perfect together.)

02/12/2014: I made it again, using the quick-cooking wild rice mix this time, and was disappointed: the boxed wild rice mix makes substantially more rice and is much better seasoned, so I will stick with my variation from now on. To make up for the lack of rice, I added a tiny bit of white rice, diced celery (two ribs), and sliced up a couple of carrots. I also added more herbs and seasonings.

text:
This was a hit with my house! I followed the directions exactly, except I took some advice from a few of the critical reviews and added some carrots, celery, and onion so that it wasn't just rice and chicken. It turned out to be wonderful! I added about 4 large carrots, 1/3 of a medium yellow-onion, and a full package of celery hearts. Also, because I wanted the celery and carrots to be nice and tender and I was a little slow on what I was adding to the broth with the rice and chicken I boiled them on the side and added them in. I used the full 2 1/2 cups of heavy cream and I thought this soup was just wonderful! Thanks, Allrecipes!

userID:
7672569
Display Name:
Mrs. Sugarbomb
isPro:

followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
40
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicioso!! I made some changes after reading others reviews. First, I boiled rice with chicken stock (instead of broth) from the beginning to cook wild rice thoroughly. Reserve 2 cups of chicken stock and keep cold in fridge. Then, I added a chopped medium sized onion and carrot each and a drained 4oz of canned mushroom. I cooked them in butter until soft before adding flour. Most importantly, before adding creamy roux mixture into the pot, add 2cups of cold stock to the mixture to prevent lumps. Oh, I used half&half, also. This soup tastes like chicken tetrazzine in soup form :)

text:
I made this soup yesterday and it was amazing! I used 1% Milk instead of heavy cream and it was still super creamy.  I also added carrots, onion & celery after I softened them up in a little butter on the stove.  Next time I will reduce the amount of flour to 1/2 cup.  I ended up having to add more broth & water because the soup was getting too thick.  My husband & 4 year old loved it!  I served it with buttermilk buiscuits for dipping.  I will be making this again!

text:
Yummy soup.  I take a short cut which always turns out fine for me.  (This can be a one pot soup!)  I finely chop garlic & onion which I add to the flour & butter.  After the roux is cooked I add the broth & water (but only 1 cup of water) & after stirred until smooth I add all the other ingredients saving the cream until last to get desired thickness.  Great with a jar of pimentos and fresh grated nutmeg added towards the end for a bit more flavor & color!

userID:
6868623
Display Name:
OwlGirl
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

5

734
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/620706.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I decided to make this one night when my mother was busy and I felt like cooking something new.
Like the other reviews, I added some vegetables: chopped up carrots, green onions, a little red onion, mushrooms, celery, and two cloves of garlic, which I sauteed before putting in the soup. I also followed the advice of one review and used 2% milk instead of heavy cream, 6 tablespoons of butter, and only 1/2 cup of flour.
I didn't use the seasoning packet from the rice boxes, and I'm glad I made that choice. Instead I used some basil, celery salt, lemon peel, parsley leaf, a small pinch of oregano, and possibly a little bit of dill weed, all along with the salt and black pepper the recipe calls for.
When I sauteed the chicken, I added some pepper to it just to add a little flavor to the meat itself.

Overall, this soup was a big hit with the family. Out of a giant pot of soup, only one serving was left over. I will definitely be making this again in the dead of winter.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
To make this recipe gluten free, use corn starch instead of flour. Mix the corn starch in with a little water and then add directly to the pot, don't boil it with the butter. The corn starch will clump if you try to heat it with the butter in a pan.  I removed the butter and poured everything directly into the pot and boiled it there. The corn starch thickens it up, just keep adding until it's the thickness that you want.

text:
I love this soup. I have tweaked it a bit. A day ahead I boil split chicken breast with some carrots, celery, and onions to make my broth. When that's done, I put it in the fridge and finish the next day. Then I will skim off the fat and pull my chicken off the bone while the broth is re-heating. I also use skim condensed milk instead of cream and don't add any of the butter. I add a can of cream of mushroom soup at the end. Delicious and I can't make too much with a house full of teen-age boys. Thank you.

text:
What a great base recipe! I used frozen chicken tenders that I roasted in the oven using this recipe: Butter Roast Chicken. I browned two slices of bacon and added diced onion, sweet potato, figs and dried ancho chiles to the pot, letting them cook while the chicken finished up. Then I added the chicken and all its roasting sauce to the pot.  I used boxed couscous instead of rice, and 2/3s 2% milk and 1/3 coconut milk instead of cream (can you tell this was a pantry clearing day?!)  I've never made a roux before, and this one turned out fabulously!! I served with cheesy chive cornbread.

text:
I made this with 1 cup heavy cream and 1 cup fat free half and half (I just couldn't stomach the thought of all of that cream). I also backed off a bit on the butter, probably used 1/3 cup.  The results were very good, although EXTREMELY rich for my husband and myself.   I would cut back even more on the butter and use only the fat free half and half, or mixture of milk and heavy cream.  Rich Rich Rich, but I would make again with a few more adjustments.  Really nice and easy to make.

I made this Dec. 26 with leftover turkey stock while drinking chardonney and listening to Leroy Anderson's Christmas Sleigh Ride...just waiting to feed the boys!  I modified a bit.  Half the flour and butter and half cream and 1% milk.  I also put in 2 generous tablespoons of leftover gravy from the turkey last night. My first time making a cream soup and it definately won't be my last. Thanks for the great ideas on this site!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I would give it 5 stars, but I made the following modifications:  2 chicken breasts, cubed (Browned with a few shakes of Old Bay) 1 can of chunk chicken in water (because I didn't want to open another pack of chicken for one more breast) 1/4 c. chopped celery  1/4 c. chopped baby carrots  1/2 c. chopped medium onion 1 6 oz pkg of Uncle Ben's Long Grain and Wild Rice, Herbed Chicken seasoning subbed 1 c. heavy cream/1 c. milk for 2 c. milk.  cut back flour from 3/4 c. to 1/3 c.  I browned all chicken in 1 T. olive oil while cooking the rice. When chicken was brown, I put it in the pot with the water/broth, boiled, then added the rice. Then in 1/3 c. butter, I sauteed the veggies until soft and tossed them in with the chicken and rice to simmer. I followed the recipe as listed from 2. onward. This is a great base recipe--we will certainly be making this soup again!

text:
Very yummy soup. At others' suggestions, I added celery and carrots.  In hind-sight, I would cook them with the chicken for flavor, but leave them out of the soup.  I substituted a tablespoon for bacon grease 1 T of butter.  Another poster had mentioned they used Rice-A-Roni instead of Uncle Ben's.  One important thing to note (and I didn't until it was too late) is that the seasoning packet has the wild rice, which takes much longer to cook.  I had to fish it out and cook the soup longer to compensate of the lack of cooking time.  Will make it again, but will probably replace at least some of the cream b/c this recipe has got to be a KILLER in calories!

text:
Sometimes following the reviews is good, sometimes not.  I'm just finishing up the soup and I took others' advice and added shredded carrots (what I had), mushrooms (thrown in too so they didn't go to waste), and about 1/4 c. of onion.  I also reduced the amount of flour (as some recommended) since I used the uncle ben's rice (6 oz. box), and I was just looking at the soup trying to figure out why it wasn't thick like I was expecting.  It had to be because of the reduced amount of flour (only used about 1/4 c. as a reviewer suggested), and because I like my soups thick, it's not enough.  I wish I would've used the whole 3/4 c., but I'll know better next time.  The flavor is delicious, and there will definitely be a next time.  If I would've followed the directions, it would've been 5 stars, so I gave it that anyway.

text:
Oh my! This was delicious!  I love creamy soups and this didn’t disappoint!  I didn’t use instant rice because I had a box of the regular rice at home, so I made that separately and omitted the water from the broth portion of the recipe (but next time I will use instant, it would be so much easier).  I also cut the butter and flour in half and used non-fat half & half to make it a bit healthier (although I bet it would be very good with the full butter and cream version too).  And as other reviewers suggested I sautéed some onion, mushrooms and carrots to throw in to make it a hardier soup.  It was amazing! I cant wait to eat the leftovers!

text:
Very good soup especially on a very chilly and rainy night. Like some others, I felt the soup needed to be bumped up with more seasonings and to make life a bit easier, I just used my microwave to cook the rice by itself. I had carrots and celery on hand, so that also went into the mix and I think peas would be another nice addition in the future. I only used three tablespoons of butter and one tablespoon of evoo to make my roux and the soup came out to a perfect consistency. Fat free half and half replaced the heavy cream and no one was the wiser. A sprinkling of some shredded cheddar and a little paprika topped it off nicely. Delish Stephanie and thank you!

text:
Husband raved and raved about this soup. I know people don't like it when the recipe is changed up so much but I find the reviews helpful. Anyways, I used leftover chicken from a roast I made earlier and a 8.8oz package of Uncle Ben's 90 second rice (that's all I could find). I cut the flour to 1/4 cup but would probably use more next time. I also used 1 C of Heavy Cream and 1 C of Skim Milk (that's all I had) and omitted the salt. One last change, I sauteed an onion before the broth step, like others have suggested. My husband does not like to eat anything with bones in it so he's not a fan of my roasted chicken. BUT he said that he'd like me to roast chicken more often if only to make this soup. =) That's a definite winner in my book.
