text:
AMAZING!!!  We loved this soup!  I made my own broth the normal chicken soup way and after all the ingredients were mixed and creamy I left it in the crock pot adding about 2tsp each (that's because I doubled the recipe - only use 1 tsp if using the recipe as is) of ground thyme, poultry seasoning and salt.  I also added the leftover white rice I had in the fridge.  You can season to your liking - either way there's no going wrong with this soup.  Even my 10 year old loved it and he's not a huge soup fan.  :)

text:
What an intoxicating recipe!  Honestly, I never follow recipes exactly because I know what I like and dislike, so I typically use them as a base.  This recipe was a great place to start!  I poached my chicken in a whole bottle of white wine, garlic and peppercorn, added the wild rice with seasoning (Zattaran's doesn't separate the two) and another box of rice (Herb and Butter).  I sauteed my onion and more garlic in butter, added the flour and Herb and Butter rice seasoning to make the roux.  I probably used more cream than called for, but fortunately, I'm not counting calories!  Added the chicken/wine/rice mixture and an extra cup of water and voila!  Amazing, amazing, amazing!

userID:
748483
Display Name:
Kaleena Machado
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
280
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7076160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a few changes, nothing tooo major though.  First change, the box of wild rice I used was a 6.2oz Uncle Ben's. Also, I used 1% milk instead of cream because that's what I had. Then, I diced up about a 1/2 lb of bacon and cooked it in a pan. I set the bacon aside, and drained the grease from the pan (but didn't wash the pan). I sauteed an onion (about a medium sized onion) and 2 cloves of garlic in the leftover bacon greased pan, when they were almost done, I added about a 1/2 cup shredded carrots to the pan. I added this to the pot with the chicken and broth.  When making the cream, I reduced the flour to 1/2 cup, because I added an 8oz block of velveeta.   When I added everything all together in the same pot, I added about another 1/2 cup of shredded carrots to the pot. I saved the bacon bits to crumble on top of my bowl of soup.  The taste is amazing! Although some may want more broth...(in which case, if you add more broth, you may want to keep the original 3/4 cup of flour to keep it somewhat thick), I didn't mind, maybe it seemed like there was a little less broth than should have been because I used more rice.

text:
I, like others added sauteed onoins and shredded carrots. I didn't have any celery or i would have added some too. This is definitely a great Base recipe for chicken and rice soup, but again, i, like others felt something was missing even after i added 2 boullion cubes!! The soup has a great taste and texture, and although when milk and half & half was substituted for the heavy cream it still was thick enough. Ultimately, this recipe is definitely a keeper with minor modifications. I think next time i make this is will add a dash of poultry seasoning to the chicken when i cook it. Something is definitely missing from this recipe that i can't quite put my finger on.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/178570.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This took me by surprise! I made this almost to a T with an addition of a  cup of sauteed onions and a clove of garlic. I also didn't have two cups cream because my boyfriend had used some of it for a coffee filler. So only using 1 3/4 c. made this soup thick but still really delicious. Now that it has settle and cooled a lot of the sauce has either thickened or evaporated, so it will be thicker as left overs, but nothing that additional liquid cant handle. I used Uncle Ben's Sun Dried Tomato and Florentine wild rice which was wonderful, I was so surprised with the amount of dried herbs, however a bit on the high side of sodium so look out. This is a bit lengthy to make, especially since I baked my chicken first and then let it cool a little in order to shred it, but it was truly an astounding meal that I will definitely make again.

This is so yummy!!!!  I took reviewers suggestions and sauteed onion, and garlic in a little butter, then added thinly sliced carrots to soften, and celery seed (I do not like chunks of celery in things). I followed the recipe directions, but my rice had a hard time softening.  Next time I will boil my rice for a few minutes and then cover and remove from heat. Either way, SO delicious!!!!!!

text:
Wish I could give this 4 1/2 stars.  I made a number of the modifications recommended by others (less flour, 1 c fat free 1/2 & 1/2 and 1 c heavy cream, and a splash of white wine).  I also used a rotisserie chicken.  I also sauteed 2 shallots, some minced garlic and 4-5 baby carrots and added those.  I also added more salt and pepper as the soup was simmering (especially pepper).  I found the soup to be really good and flavorful.  My only complaint is that the rice wasn't as cooked as it needed to be.  Just slightly too "al dente."    Otherwise, delish!

text:
I've made this several times now, each time a bit different, but this is the base I always start with. I never make the roue, just throw everything into the pot, bring to boil and then simmer for 30 minutes. I too add additional veggies, onions, carrots, peas, corn, celery, and garlic. Each time it's a bit different as it depends on what I've got in the house. Also, instead of the cream I drop a brick of fat free or low fat cream cheese in near the end. Once it melts, its just a wonderful soup. I've cut so many corners and changed so many things it's not really fair to call this the same soup, but I always reference this as the starting point.

text:
I just made this today and it is fab!!!  I took the suggestions of other reviewers and added some minced carrot, onion and celery by cooking briefly in olive oil.  I did not get the fast cook wild rice so I increased the water by about 1 1/2 cups and let it simmer for 25 minutes unstead of stand off the heat.  I used one cup of heavy cream and one cup of half and half.  Additionally I only needed one quarter cup of the flour mixture.  The soup came out beautifully (eye appealing) and so full of flavor.  I have my bread maching going now and can't wait to serve this delightful meal to my family.  Try this, you won't be sorry.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a vegetarian version of this soup - and what a delight!  The substitutions made were three Russet potatoes for the chicken, low-sodium vegetable broth for the chicken broth, whole wheat flour for the all-purpose flour, and 1.5% milk for the cream.  I also halved the butter, added a package of frozen veggies (onion, celery, carrot), and ground a bunch of sea salt into the pot.  We had wild rice already cooked so I obviously used that.  I cooked everything as directed, then let it sit out for four hours before re-heating and eating.  This turned out to be QUITE the soup/stew - creamy and delicious!

text:
Very quick and easy. I converted it to make 8 servings. It called for 1/2 cup butter and 3/4 flour, it didn't need that much roux, it was way too thick. I would use 1/4 butter and 3-4 Tbl flour. The one box of rice was not enough for 8 servings so I stirred in some instant brown rice, and Viola it was great!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed Carrie's lead and sautéed 1/2 C. each of onion, celery and carrots w/ 1 tsp minced garlic. I used the food processor instead of hand chopping. I used the leftover breast from a store bought rotisserie chicken and the juice. I also used the food processor instead of shredding the chicken. I used 2 C. fat free half and half, 6 Tbsp margarine and 1/2 C flour.  I added about 1/4 C more broth at the end because it was really thick.  

The soup was very hearty and was flavorful yet mild.  Very comforting.  A meal in itself.

text:
awesome soup. Here's a little secret instead of 2 cups heavy creame do 1 cup heavy creame 1 cup milk depending on how thick you want it. Also make it a few hours ahead of time and put it in a crock-pot or slow-cooker and put it on the low setting until you re ready to eat it. Als throw in some mushrooms, fabulous.

text:
WOW!  What a great cold weather easy recipe.  I read many other reviews and used many of their ideas (saute veggies best idea).  I also use the larger box of wild rice.  I accidentally box the regular rice (not fast cooking).  I just cooked the rice (just short of recommended time) and didn't add the 2 cups of water.  I also use 2% milk or whole milk and not cream-still delicious.  And I did decrease the flour amount (per many, many other reviews).
I can't say enough how delicious this soup is and will part of my regular recipe rotation.

text:
This tasted great and was very easy! Similar to Panera's version. Couldn't find 4.5 oz quick-cook rice mix, so used box of Uncle Ben's regular wild rice mix, which was 5 or 6 oz - worked perfectly, the extra rice didn't make a difference. And since it wasn't quick-cook, simmered it about 10 min longer. For additional texture, included sauteed onions, carrots, and potatoes. Used 1% milk instead of cream. Didn't add extra salt and still had great flavor. My 2.5 yr old ate it 3 days in a row. To reheat, added milk until reached desired consistency. Makes a BIG pot. Will make it again.

This was the greatest soup I have made in years! This made the soup slightly less thick the first day but today it is perfect!  Thanks for a fantastic recipe filled with endless possibilities!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was good.  Since I realized that I didn't have butter, I made the roux using 1/4 cup oil and 3 heaping tablespoons of flour.  I couldn't find 4.5 oz. package of wild rice so I used 6.2 oz. package of Uncle Ben's Quick Cooking Wild Rice.  When I added the cream mixture to chicken/rice mixture, my soup didn't get as thick as I hoped after 10 minutes so I mixed another heaping tablespoon in a little water until it dissolved and then mixed it in to the soup.  I cooked it for a bit longer than specified in the directions (probably about 30 minutes total) to get it to thicken.  I added a sliced carrot when I added the cream mixture in.  I did wish that they were cooked a little longer and that there were more.

I'll definitely make this again, but for the roux use 1/3 cup oil plus 4 or 5 tablespoons of flour and add 2 sliced carrots to the chicken broth right away.

text:
I would have to say that this soup has to be one of the more hearty. I added mushrooms to give it more substance but regardless is very flavorful. With the season packet I got from a Wild Rice from Uncle Bens, the soup was too salty and I had to compromise the flavor by adding water. When I make this dish again, I'd do either two things, not add salt or add 3/4 of the season packet form the wild rice. I do believe that with those change, this would be a restaurant quality soup dish.

text:
I'm on a diet, so I made a few changes to make it more figure friendly... soooo yummy!!!  First I sauteed onion and celery in fat free butter before adding the broth.  I used all broth and no water.  I also substituted couscous for rice since it has more protein and fiber.  I probably only used about 2 tablespoons of butter for the whole recipe.  I also used fat free half and half and only 1/4 a cup of soy flour.  It still came out really thick and delicous!  One of the best soups ever!

Great recipe. I change it a little after reading one of the posts taht stated it lacked flavor. text:
Homerun! This soup recipe is teriffic. I tried it for the first time about a week ago and it's definitely going in the keeper box. This tastes teriffic and the entire family loved it! I followed the recipe exactly with the exception of replacing the heavy cream with half and half (same amounts) and I added a little more wild rice. Other than that, don't change a thing. If you want to add veggies, boil them in 2 cups of chicken broth and then add them about half way through the cooking time for the soup. When you want to heat up the leftovers, I would add a little milk because this soup gets really thick once you stick it in the fridge. Great recipe!!!

This recipe was awesome!  After looking at several reviews, I put them together on what would work best.  I sauteed half cup of each: onion, carrots, and celery, in butter and garlic, after they were soft, I added, the broth and water, then the chicken.  I made the roux with half and half, and added a little less than half a cup of flour slowly (plenty thick). Added rice to other pot, then slowly stirred in cream mixture.  Cook for a little while to absorb chunks, perfect.

text:
I wish I could give this more stars! I couldn't find the quick cook rice called for so I used Mahatmas Long Grain & Wild Rice. The recipe calls for reserving the spice packet to be mixed with the roux, but since Mahatmas combines the rice with the spices I couldn't. I just cooked the rice, spices and all, and added it to the soup. I added onion, carrots, corn, a dash of garlic powder and the flavor was sooo good! Last thing: I mistakenly grabbed half/half instead of heaving cream, and still the soup was perfectly thick. And delicious! You cannot go wrong with this recipe. Try it!

text:
This is the best creamy chicken and wild rice soup I have ever had.  Easy and very tasty!  I made a few minor alterations.  I used 2 cans of chicken broth (not quite 4 cups).  I added a little extra water and a tablespoon of chicken bouillon granules.  I also added one stalk of celery and about 10 sliced baby carrots.  I used a pint of half and half.  Next time I will add a little more liquid.  It turned out pretty thick.

If I could give this ten stars, I would. I used a premade rotisserie chicken because of time contraints and also used NON-instant rice.  I cooked the rice separately and added it to the soup.  The CREAMIEST, most wonderful rice soup I've ever hand. Beats even Panera Breads!

I have a new favorite to make with left over rotisserie chicken!

text:
This soup was easy and tasty. I did not have already cooked chicken so I boiled the chicken in broth and then shredded it, put it back in the pot and followed the recipe from there. This is a thick soup, which I like, but it is more of a chowder consistency. I used light cream which is what I had but probably would just use milk next time so it's not quite as thick. Definately needs seasoning, I used salt and pepper, garlic powder and a little crushed red pepper. I also added a can of corn which I think went really well with it. Will definately make again.

text:
I made this recipe exactly as it called for, but the roux seemed very thick when I added the cream already.  I let it cook a while, but it formed a really thick paste.  I thought the recipe was going to be a bust, but I continued and once the roux and broth cooked together for 10 minutes or so, it did thicken and the soup was nice and creamy.  After eating about a half a serving though, the intense flavor did get a bit overwhelming with every bite.  I did freeze half of it to have at a later date, but I don't know if I would make it again...

Simply AMAZING! I doubled the recipe useing 2 boxes of uncle bens wild rice, cooking the chicken breasts in chicken broth, cooking the rice separetly, and sauteing the veggies then using the same broth I cooked the chicken in, added the veggies and rice to it- and finally after cutting up the chicken added it then finished with the half and half I used.I took servings to several friends and all they could do was rave and ask for more! I did take some out and blend it in the blender w/some half and half - I also added a TB of cornstarch to some broth at the end - Will be making this again and again!  thanks for a super recipe
